Resolves #1304

Also considered using an IntentService or another background class.
Problem: At least two activities and one fragment react to the completed deletion in similar, but different ways. An IntentService could just send ProgressEvents, but the MainActivity would need some mechanism to find out what ("FeedRemover") actually completed.

title: Feed Remover: Don't let the user cancel the ProgressDialog

body:
The best example is when your device is paired with a car stereo.  AntennaPod will start playback as soon as the device connects to the car.  However, the car stereo may not have the Bluetooth source selected. As a result AntennaPod podcasts will be playing through episodes, but the user will have no idea this is happening. As far as they're concerned they just started their car and are driving somewhere listening to the radio/cd/nothing.

One thought for how to resolve this so that it works properly for people with Bluetooth headsets is to have a setting that determines if AntennaPod will start playback on bluetooth reconnect.  It has also been suggested that AntennaPod should vibrate some when it starts playback due to a Bluetooth reconnect.

This behavior changed in AntennaPod 1.4 alpha, so I think we should try to resolve it before we release 1.4.
title: Starting Bluetooth playback on reconnect doesn't always work correctly

body: AntennaPod currently resumes playing from the position where it was paused, but it would be nice to have an option to rewind a predetermined amount of time when resuming playback. The best solution would be to make the amount of time to rewind a function of the amount of time occurred between pause and resume, up to a certain limit, like 30 seconds or so. For example, it would rewind 10 seconds if we paused for 20 seconds or rewind 20 seconds if we paused for 40. If we paused for a minute or more, it would rewind 30 seconds.
title: Feature request: Option to rewind a bit when resuming playback

Phone: Motorola Moto X 2011
Android Version: 5.1
Kernel version: 3.4.42-g756aa87
AntennaPod version: 1.4.0.2

I use my phone with two different Bluetooth audio devices. These devices both include one "forward" and one "back" button. In the past, these buttons mapped to the in-track Rewind and Fast Forward functions, which would step back/forward some number of seconds. I liked that.

It looks like this functionality changed. It seems now that the "back" hardware button on my Bluetooth devices does nothing within AntennaPod, while the "forward" button now skips to the next podcast file instead of fast forwarding in the current track.

Unfortunately, I am unable to say with confidence if this change came about because of a recent update to AntennaPod, or with the recent upgrade my phone experienced from Android KitKat to Lollipop. Please feel free to swat this down if you're confident that no such changes were made on the AntennaPod side, or if this working as intended.

Thanks for your consideration.
title: Buttons on bluetooth devices skip track instead of fast forwarding

body:
As @TomHennen suggested in https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/1152#issuecomment-138323471, I've been working on re-writing the app description.

**Below is my proposal. If you feel like adapting it, it's easiest to go over to [this TitanPad](https://titanpad.com/9y3ic3NMWv).** Please do fill in your GitHub username if you make changes; it makes any discussion easier. Please also provide some explanation if you changed things in the chat facility there.

I'll only do a PR to change https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/develop/description/en.txt if some consensus has been reached on the change (hence the TitanPad).

# Proposed description
With AntennaPod you get instant access to millions of free and paid podcasts, from independent podcasters to large publishing houses such as the BBC, NPR and CNN. Add, import and export their feeds hassle-free using the iTunes podcast database, OPML files or simple RSS URLs. Save effort, battery power and mobile data usage with powerful automation controls for downloading episodes (specify times, intervals and WiFi networks) and deleting episodes (based your favourites and delay settings).

But most importantly: Download, stream or queue episodes and enjoy them the way you like with adjustable playback speeds, chapter support and a sleep timer. And show your podlove to the content creators with our Flattr integration.

Made by podcast-enthousiast, AntennaPod is free in all senses of the words: open source, no costs, no ads.

All features:
* Easily add and import feeds via the iTunes and gPodder.net directories, OPML files and RSS or Atom links
* Manage playback from anywhere: homescreen widget, system notification and earplug and bluetooth controls
* Enjoy listening your way with adjustable playback speed, chapter support (MP3, VorbisComment and Podlove) and an advanced sleep timer (shake to reset, lower volume and slow down playback)
* Take control over automated downloading: choose feeds, exclude mobile networks, select specific WiFi networks, require the phone to be charging and set times or intervals
* Manage storage by setting the amount of cached episodes, smart deletion (based on your favourites and play status) and selecting your preferred location
* Share episodes and feeds through advanced social media and email options, the gPodder.net services and via OPML export
* Support content creators with Flattr integration including automatic flattring
* Keep track of the best of the best by marking episodes as favourites
* Find back that one episode through the playback history or by searching (titles and shownotes)
* Access password-protected feeds and episodes
* Take advantage of paged feeds (www.podlove.org/paged-feeds)
* Back-up your subscriptions with the gPodder.net integration and OPML export
title: Updated description

body:
Often, but I can't tell in which cases exactly, the playback position of an item regularly moves back to pre-last position after pause. What I mean with that is:
- I play an item and pause it (playback time A). (some stuff happens in between) then play again and pause again (playback time B)
- when resuming the play again, the progress bar and currently playing position show correct data (playback time B) for half a second or so, but then changes to playback time A.

What I don't know:
- if it happens only when I pause it via the lock screen, or when playback gets paused when I unplug my earbuds, or when I manually pause it in the playing bar at the bottom or the system notification
- if it happens with certain 'some stuff happens in between' (i.e. play another item, refresh feeds, shutdown phone, check email, etc)
- if it also happens if I only paused once (playback time A being 0, basically) [I think it does sometimes, but I'm not sure]

This issue has been present for quite a while (throughout some different versions). Don't know why I only reported it now. I have not enabled prestissimo. The issue plays up I think for different feeds.

I found it rather cumbersome to note down every single pause and the consequence in daily use (playback gets paused rather often) and thus I didn't do it. Any feedback on if it's really necessary to do so (to provide more detailed info) or on other means of getting more detailed info is appreciated.

AP v. 1.3.4.1 on Android 4.2.2

PS. My quick-fix is to pay attention to the position when I hit play, so that I can manually scroll to that position again.
title: Playback position regularly moves back to pre-last position after pause

body:
This pull request resolves #620 feature request.

The playback is rewinded X seconds after the pause and resume. The rewind duration depends on time that elapsed between the pause and resume. User is not able to customize the rewind duration right now.

I have chosen following constants (can be easily changed):
- podcast rewinds:
  - 0 seconds - if pause < 3 minutes
  - 2 seconds - if pause > 3 minutes
  - 5 seconds - if pause > 1 hour
  - 10 seconds - if pause > 1 day

I have chosen these constants based on my gut feelings and observation of the other apps such as Audible.
title: Rewind after pause feature

body:
Recently I tried to listen to the System Mastery podcast. The feed's here:

http://feeds.feedburner.com/SystemmasteryPodcasts?format=xml

It's hosted on Wordpress. The feed loads fine but I get a PROTOCOL_ERROR in AntennaPod. I get the same error in Pocketcasts. The audio files download just fine with desktop clients, curl, etc. The System Mastery folks are at a loss as they didn't change anything, but were getting reports from their users things didn't work properly.

I went looking around and found this issue:

https://github.com/square/okhttp/issues/1897

so it's possible that there is some change in Android 5.x that in combination with a server change (HTTP 2 support on part of Wordpress?) triggers this problem.

I recently learned another podcast, Heavy Cardboard, also hosted on Wordpress, is experiencing very similar issues with Pocket Casts. According to them Pocket Casts is working on a fix but I figured I'd inform you too.

http://feeds.feedburner.com/HeavyCardboardPodcast?format=xml
title: PROTOCOL_ERROR

body:
1. Added a idle sync at some key points to make sure all the actions were actually done.
1. Instead of using a stand-alone PlaybackController we're using the external controller since the stand-alone controller wasn't always notified when media was initially loaded (I suspect media was started in more than loadMediaInfo when playback first starts).  This _should_ be more realistic in the long run.
1. Resolved one or two conditional tests that were actually testing the wrong thing

body:
Hi! We are 3 university students that are doing a course in software engineering and the goal of the course is to take a application like antennapod which we have choosen to do and to investigate it like software architecture design strategies and so on. We also have to investigate different design patterns which has been implemented in this application where we chose Observer Pattern, Singleton and Adaptor.  We would like to double check that these patterns are being used in this application!? 

Another problem, for our next task we need to do a change/feature request, As this is a pretty large application and we are planning to do a bug fix/ change request. A couple of days ago there was a change request about changing the background color for something in the application. We were planning to take that but we can not find it anymore so we figured that someone did it already. Are there any other easy change requests that the community has that we can do for our project?

(At the end of the project, we will have to submit a pull request so that we "give back" to the community)

Thanks for Helping us out!!
Vikhram - Luleå University of Technology

body:
Phone: Motorola Moto X 2011
Android Version: 5.1
Kernel version: 3.4.42-g756aa87
AntennaPod version: 1.3.4.1

I have my phone synced to my car's Bluetooth, and am able to play audio. When I turn off the car, playback pauses, as expected. But when I then hit "play" on the phone, the progress bar does not activate, and the "play" button does not change to "pause". I need to then open up Android's task manager, kill AntennaPod, then open it again, at which point I see a popup stating that the AntennaPod app had crashed. I click OK, open AntennaPod again, and now playback starts working again.

In fact, the same scenario plays out when I go from playing on my phone's speaker, to starting playback over Bluetooth.
This bug was first noticed after both upgrading AntennaPod to 1.3.4.1, and upgrading my Android OS from 4.4 to 5.1.
title: Bug: AntennaPod crashes when resuming on phone after disconnecting bluetooth

body:
Here I am on my vacation submitting updates...

fixes #1234 and fixes #1060 

Preferences now has an 'Episode Cleanup' option that allows the user to specify how they want their episodes removed or deleted. The default is "if it isn't in the queue or favorites then it is eligible to be deleted if stuff needs to be downloaded".  However the user may override this and choose some other other setting.  They may choose "never' or any of 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7 days after the episode has completed playback.

I'm open to any suggestions on how/if things should be reworded.

I'm also willing to entertain some sort of indicator on an episode (perhaps in Completed Downloads) that shows it is eligible for deletion.  I have *no* idea what that indicator should look like though.

I also went through and fixed the PreferencesTest which wasn't checking the results of waitForCondition().

![device-2015-10-02-165820](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216560/10257690/df66355e-6926-11e5-9ff2-75c2ad425fc3.png)
![device-2015-10-02-165824](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216560/10257691/df683d54-6926-11e5-9f66-54da15604455.png)

body:
Sometimes I want to re-listen to an episode after I've finished it. Sometimes because I did not understand or did not pay attention to some detail, or because I want to investigate further on something that was said, or even because I want to play the episode (or a portion of it) to a friend.

For such reasons, I do not want to auto-remove episodes as soon as they are finished. Instead, I'd prefer to have an option to auto-remove finished episodes after 1 day, or 2 days, or 7 days, …


Currently, I have to either manually delete the episodes, which is a pain; or to re-download an episode (which can be impossible if I'm not on a good Wi-Fi).
title: Feature request: auto-remove played episodes after a delay

Audio players were moved to an external library.

While testing the new sonic audio player, I got annoyed with test failures not actually caused by the changes, so I replaced some of the AsyncTasks with RxJava. At last, I managed to run all (new) sonic tests successfully. Using the new player in the app has been no issue, so far (Honestly, can't remember a single issue...)

Still, tests fail once in a while (e.g. in teardown(), saying that the database pool has already been closed). I tend to have a quick look and if it is one of the usual suspects, I just ignore it...
Another source of errors is the custom UndoBar thingy, which will hopefully be replaced by Snackbar soon.

Also fixed the about link handling, which was already part of the retracted #1208

Resolves #1203

Instead of replacing a few special characters that we know are not allowed in filenames, only allow that few characters (alphanumeric, spaces and so on) that are unproblematic.

Also considered applying this the generation of the directory name, but I fear this could break backward compatibility. Current feeds with special characters in their title (that might create issues on some devices or file systems) could end up with a second directory for their media files.
While this would probably not be a problem I didn't want to risk fixing one issue and creating another.

All tests completed successfully.
title: Allow only alphanumeric and a few other characters in media filenames

body:
![lockscreen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/9860746/4ea2d2ee-5b2e-11e5-801c-c6cf8c11c1c0.png)
(Cover of http://www.npr.org/sections/money/)

The next button doesn't actually mean there is another episode in the queue, it might end the playback altogether.

APod is now able to set the lockscreen background. It is a preference: There are probably a lot of people that prefer their own background image to the episode image on the lockscreen.
Maybe "lockscreen background" is a bit misleading: Basically, any other app/service that is "listening" (that receives MediaSession information) can read that image and show it. If enabled, watch apps will also be able to show the cover. "Cover art"? Not sure it this is any better, might only be more confusing.
Because of Glide, the meta data is updated in a background thread. Not sure if executing on the executor service is the best idea or if this should just run in its own thread... I guess we'll see if this leads to unwanted behavior

Receiving media button events from external apps also seems to work now.

Resolve #762
title: Lockscreen background, media session and playback state

body:
Code changes inspired by https://github.com/android/platform_frameworks_base/blob/master/media/java/android/media/MediaPlayer.java

What was happening here?
When a ServiceBackedMediaPlayer was created on startup but the current episode is paused (we played an episode and restarted the app; external player is at the bottom, but paused), the media player already acquired a wakelock without needing it. This would only get justified when the user actually started playing.
So, now the wakelock is only acquired if it was held when the method was called.

Resolves #1110
title: Do not acquire wakelock when Prestissimo backed mediaplayer is created

Mostly removing the need to pass a context on every database access.
Most of the changes are pretty boring (and where refactored automatically), the interesting parts are probably ``PodDBAdapter`` and ``PlaybackTest``
Also added some null checks (when tests crashed) and replaced one or two asyntasks (Seems like the threads were not stopped immediately, so Android throw IllegalStateExceptions when the database was deleted in a tearDown but those threads still tried to access data; no problems once replaced by RxAndroid)

body:
Even when I've pre-downloaded all the podcasts in my queue and disabled mobile data updates, AntennaPod still seems to be using plenty of data during my commutes as I listen.  I have auto-downloading completely disabled and I manually queue and download each podcast while on WiFi.
Just in the last 12 hours since I installed a network monitor, AntennaPod has downloaded 39.05MB on mobile data (63.14MB on WiFi, which would account for one downloaded podcast).  During the same timeframe, Prestissimo has used 114.68MB on mobile and 19.55MB on WiFi, which could be another matter, though this is the only app I have that uses Prestissimo.
I've already reached my monthly bandwidth cap in the last ten days.
title: High mobile data usage during playback

Hi,

I'm subscribed to Radio Berkman:

http://feeds.feedburner.com/radioberkman

When I resume playing an episode after closing AntennaPod, it resumes playing at a point different than the point it was paused.  If I seek within an episode using the slider, it displays one time for a fraction of a second, then displays another time as it starts playing back.  If I seek using the Forwards and Backwards buttons, it doesn't seek by 30 seconds.  Sometimes seeking using the Backwards button will cause it to seek forwards.

Matt

body:
I synced with my gpodder.net account, which included several subscriptions that no longer have active RSS feeds.  It seems that since AntennaPod has never successfully downloaded the feed, it doesn't appear in the subscription list, so I can't remove the dead subscription.  I have unsubscribed via gpodder.net, but AntennaPod doesn't seem to be syncing the *removal* of a subscription.  As a result, every time I refresh my podcasts, I get errors for four RSS feeds that I don't have listed in my subscriptions.
Also, is there a way to get to the download history / error log from inside the app?

body:
The glide url loader now uses its own OkHttpClient.
The result is that we can now search for podcasts and download them while on mobile
even if the user doesn't allow mobile downloads (NOTE that we don't do anything
they haven't asked us to do while on mobile).

I'm not sure if this is the *right* solution, we don't load *any* images while on the mobile network this way.  It is better than the current situation where we can't really download anything while on mobile data unless the user has mobile download enabled.

fixes AntennaPod/AntennaPod#1101
title: Can now download things while on mobile.

As there are quite a few strings that haven't been translated to Dutch I am working on that in Transifex. I have the app open in front of me so that I can check for the right context.

In order to determine the the proper translation of 'Set subscription counter' (pref_nav_drawer_feed_counter_title) and the other counter items, I was wonder what the function (Setting the subscription counter) actually does:
A) determine the displayed number in the drawer
B) determine the numbers for the counter (the "set subscription order" setting 'sort by counter') and thus the order of the feeds if 'sort by counter' is selected
C) both

I would expect it's C) both, but from the english strings I would read differently, as the description of the "Set subscription counter" currently is: "Change the *information displayed* by the subscription counter"
title: Translation question: what does the drawer counter do

body:
Fixes #1086

Honestly, I'm not entirely sure why this actually works, but I tested this both on a (virtual) 4.1.1 and a 4.4.4 device.
*OkHttp* should take care of setting the socket's enabled protocols (see ConnectionSpec). I'm not familiar with OkHttp and not motivated enough to find out what exactly doesn't work here... A fix is a fix ^^

Also upgraded OkHttp to the latest version and increased the sleep time of the feed media service to 5s to be even more server friendly.

Side note: This was caused on 4.x devices by servers only allowing TLS 1.1 and 1.2, but not 1.0
I don't think this is very common. I'd rather have an insecure podcast download than nothing to play...
title: Custom SSL Socket Factory for Android 4.1.x - 4.4x

body:
With the growth of the project, the [current](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/b332942f161f598d2c3247bdd073765a8ad51662/LICENSE) license is probably no longer sufficient as it leaves much unclear and not explicit. For example, it asks for the copyright notice to be included, but doesn't say anything about whether forked code should disclose source code or not (relevant [comment](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/997#issuecomment-128245418))

It's probably a good idea for the community or maintainers to discuss/decide on a more appropriate and comprehensive license. A good summary of popular licenses is available [here](https://tldrlegal.com/). Some of the more popular licenses are listed [here](https://tldrlegal.com/verified) (scroll down). An alternative listing of popular licenses is available [here](http://choosealicense.com/licenses/).
title: License

body:
# Sleep Timer Dialog

![timer](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/9154520/936d074e-3e93-11e5-965d-3232652fee59.png)

The dialog will now remember the last settings.

I know, the layouts look redundant, but I found no other way to make the dialog look this way, e.g. if you remove the outer LinearLayout, the dialog will become very narrow.

# When timer is about to expire...

10s before the timer is about to expire, users can choose to get a short 0.5s vibration, we need a new permission here. Not sure if this may have any implications on devices with no vibrator, maybe the Play Store will tell them APod is not compatible...
In any case, the audio's volume will be lower significantly. Lowering it to 10% may look much: I tried to find a balance between still being able to hear and detecting the actual volume change [1]. 10% turned out to be the best solution for me.
Shake to reset will only work in this 10 second timeframe. I took the threshold from someone else's code - maybe we have to lower it in another commit, not sure how good people are at giving their phones/tablets a good shake (acceleration!) while lying down...
If a shake is detected, the timer will be reset to 15 mins [2], the volume will be reset to 100% as a kind of audible shake detection confirmation.

# References

Resolves #247
Improvement over #466
I'm also considering closing #228. Fading out sounds nice, but is (as already said) not noticeable enough.

--
[1] Not really sure what is up with the volume setting. I don't think it is linear... when I lowered the volume to 50% or so, the volume change would not be noticeable immediately
[2] Well, I could almost bet on a FR to make this configurable. Not sure if it is worth the effort... Getting an other EditText in the dialog without messing up the layout could be harder that it looks
title: Sleep Timer: Shake to reset, lower volume, vibrate, remember preferences

body:
After some thought and use of autodownload as it stands now, auto-downloading all unplayed episodes is just not the expected behavior for anyone.  If we autodownload all unplayed episodes then if you subscribe to a new feed all of the episodes from that feed are candidates to be autodownloaded, and they may trump other 'new' episodes from other feeds.

So, this change makes it so that only queued and new items are autodownloaded. If you want to download something else you can still click the 'Download' button and it will still be downloaded and enqueued.

As a result, I think AntennaPod/AntennaPod#1060 will probably wind up focusing on the cleanup algorithm, favorites, etc...

This also fixes a small bug that occurs when upgrading the database to set the autodownload flag to false.

refs AntennaPod/AntennaPod#1009
title: Only autodownload queued and new items

body:
There's been some confusion recently about when things get auto downloaded and when they get cleaned up.

Part of this is from actual bugs and part of it is because the functionality is just plain confusing.  The problem is that changing the behavior may break some users' workflows.  Some might say that those users' workflows should be broken, but it's probably wiser to find a solution that can make everyone happy.

To do that I'd like to propose a new workflow that will likely become the default, but give users the choice to retain the old one.

AutoDownload and Queuing
------------------
AutoDownload will download and add to the queue all items which are 'New' and have auto-download enabled (e.g. it will still support disabling downloads for individual feeds).  

It currently downloads any unread items.

An item is new if it hasn't been acted on in some way.  All new items show up in 'New Episodes' currently.  This essentially makes New Episodes the list of items that will be downloaded the next time auto download is activated.

While we think we have #1009 under control with the auto-download flag, this change would certainly have helped with it too.

Cleanup
-----------
Cleanup will consider any item that isn't currently in the queue as eligible for deletion.  Currently an item has to be fully played and not in the queue for it to be deleted.  Items won't get deleted immediately, but the next time AntennaPod needs space it will remove items that aren't queued.  This will resolve the problem of having new items but them not being downloaded because you simply removed an item you didn't care about from the queue.  Currently to make room for an item you have to mark the item as read and remove it from the queue, or go to 'Downloads' and remove it there.  Which is more complicated than needs to be.

This change to cleanup should resolve #939, #699.

Enhancements
-------------------------
Some users like to keep episodes after they've already listened to them. We could add (either now or as a future enhancement) a 'Favorites' capability (something that's been requested a number of other times). Items that are 'favorited' won't be deleted by the cleanup algorithm.  (#538, wouldn't quite be as full featured as #851, but that would be more complicated to handle from a 'don't delete this' standpoint and take more time to implement)

We might want to update what makes an item appear new. With this system an item added to the queue will never be new. A user might want to be able to see what new things have been downloaded and added the queue.  Not sure what would be a good way to indicate that.

Finally, we might want to add some ability to remove stale items from the queue. User can ask to bulk remove everything older than 7 days or something to that effect.

Transition
-------------
I think the user should be allowed to choose between this and the 'classic' algorithm, but I would like this to be the default in the future since I think it makes far more sense.  So there's a question of how to transition without having people that would prefer classic lose all their episodes.  I'd propose the following (though I'm not sure it's the best idea).

For new installs, we just default to this new algorithm.  But, if the user is upgrading, on the first launch of the app we ask the user if they want to switch to the queue centric model that allows for easier management of automatic downloads and easier cleanup of old episodes.  If they prefer they can stick with classic which downloads more things and requires more interaction to clean up old episodes.

Implementation
--------------
We'd create a new EpisodeCleanupAlgorithm and a new AutomaticDownloadAlgorithm. Choosing the new mode would use those algorithms instead of APCleanupAlgorithm and APDownloadAlgorithm.




Thoughts
-------------
Any thoughts or opinions?  Any other related issues I missed?
title: Queue centric AutoDownload and Cleanup Algorithms

body:
# Replace Glide

Picasso has been replaced by Glide. While the images are loaded, most ImageView show a grey placeholder and the name of the feed.
When a feed is downloaded/refreshed, we no longer load the feed's or its episodes images.

# Update Manager

I needed a mechanism to delete the already downloaded feed or episode images on upgrade. In the future, we can use this class whenever APod has to do upgrade maintenance.

In my tests, deleting a huge image cache could take quite a while (20-50s). So deleting is done in its own thread. In my tests, this had no impact on the running app.

# Preference: Image Cache

There is now a user preference where one can set the limit for cached images. Default: 100 MiB (Else, Glide's default would be 250 MiB)
(FYI, 1 MiB or Mebibyte = 1.048.576 bytes, 1 MB or megabyte = 1.000.000 bytes...)

![pref](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/9012995/71aabae2-37b9-11e5-8b02-3372ef28bf90.png)

# Datetime parser fixes

When I loaded APod with nearly 100 podcasts, I noticed that some feeds' pubdates could not be parsed. Some of the dates looked correct, but hat multiple consecutive spaces. Another feed used the [*ANSI C's asctime() format*](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec3.html) which is UTC bases and does not include timezone information.
title: Glide

body:
On previous installed version I had auto download enabled in settings (disabled for three feeds), no WiFi filtering. 

After installing the alfa I at first didn't change any settings, two days later I hadn't received any new podcasts (at this time I didn't check if any new episodes where available, but given the release schedule of my subscriptions there should have been some) so I went into the settings and checked to see if automatic download was still enabled, it was, I also set a download time (2 am). Today, two days later, I still hadn't gotten any new episodes so I went into each podcast feed (from the sidebar) and refreshed the feeds. It found 12 new episodes and the automatic download started.
title: Autodownload doesn't refresh feeds automatically (Alpha)

body:
Problem: Per default, auto downloading was enabled for all episodes when it was introduced. Now, some users complain that (older) episodes are downloaded twice (or again).

Solution: We disable auto downloading for all episodes that are marked as played, have a position > 0 (partially played) or are currently downloaded (all actions, that would disable auto downloading now).
We exclude episodes that are currently in the queue.

Possible new issues: There might be users that performed an action that automatically disabled auto downloading (like downloading or playing) and manually re-activated auto downloading. These users will lose their manual change.

Fixes #1009

Also changed: The DB version now reflects the app's code version. This will make it a lot easier to see when database migrations were performed.

Why I did not use variables in the SQL you ask? My reasoning: I know the tables and columns names for that particular version upgrade. When someone changes these constants in the future, this person will break the migration. IMHO it makes sense to not use variables here.
title: Retro-actively disable auto download for older episodes

body:
I noticed the following exception via Google Play

```
java.util.ConcurrentModificationException
at java.util.ArrayList$ArrayListIterator.next(ArrayList.java:573)
at java.util.AbstractCollection.toString(AbstractCollection.java:372)
at java.util.Collections$UnmodifiableCollection.toString(Collections.java:994)
at java.lang.StringBuilder.append(StringBuilder.java:202)
at de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.GpodnetSyncService.syncEpisodeActions(GpodnetSyncService.java:207)
at de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.GpodnetSyncService.sync(GpodnetSyncService.java:120)
at de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.GpodnetSyncService.access$100(GpodnetSyncService.java:45)
at de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.GpodnetSyncService$1.onWaitCompleted(GpodnetSyncService.java:323)
at de.danoeh.antennapod.core.service.GpodnetSyncService$WaiterThread$1.run(GpodnetSyncService.java:359)
```

When I investigated I discovered that GpodnetPreferences was very inconsistent with how it handled locking.  I believe I've improved things.

I also removed 'testAbout' because it took so long and didn't add much (though we may discover in the future that some link died).
title: Fix locking in GpodnetPreferences

body:
Fixes a couple of problems with Time of Day automatic refreshing:
* It was getting refreshed too many times. It was using .before() to determine if it should add a day, but it also needs to use .equals(), otherwise the alarm can trigger multiple times.
* It was using refreshExpiredFeeds() which was broken since it assumed getUpdateInterval() was the only game in town (it isn't since it doesn't handle time of day updates).   getExpiredFeeds() was also using the wrong units for getUpdateInterval() (it returns hours, but getExpiredFeeds() assumed it was millis) so it was just pretty much always refreshing all the feeds anyways.

I also fixed a test that was broken with some prior changes to Add Podcast.
title: Fix Time of Day Refresh

body:
Being far more conservative when we check for sizes of items.

@mfietz could you review? I'm open to other ways to solve this problem.
title: Fix1026

body:
Currently it tries to download the size for every item, even if we already have the size.

There are a couple of reasons:
* getFeedMediaUnknownSizeCursor() should check if KEY_SIZE <= 0, but it checks > Integer.MIN_VALUE, which is everything
* Some servers always return 0 for this query, so we'll just always ask how big they are:
(example showing some logging that has been added)
```
07-19 21:59:31.030: D/FeedMediaSizeService(21038): Getting size currently 0 for https://my.slate.com/subscriptions/media/3c83...........mp3
07-19 21:59:31.466: D/FeedMediaSizeService(21038): Size now: 0
```
* It should probably only check on sizes if isDownloadAllowed(), not just if networkAvailable().
title: FeedMediaSizeService is overactive

body:
An option to change playback speed to a lower (when listening to foreign language or otherwise difficult podcasts) or higher (easy listening) setting would be very appreciated.

This could probably be integrated in the interface by adding a button on the right of the playback controls in the player view, which would trigger a pop-up menu with available speeds, Youtube-style, or a separate pop-up with a slider.

However, a brief search reveals that the Android API by default does not include a functionality to change playback speed. See [this Android issue] and also [this SO question]. So this FR will probably have to sit here for quite a while, unless someone decides to re-implement variable playback rate, or Google suddenly releases an update.

I might have been mistaken though, as I am poorly familiar with the details of Android development, so someone should look into whether this is actually impossible with the current API.

[this Android issue]: https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=1961
[this SO question]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5149050/changing-the-speed-of-music-playback-in-android
title: Feature request: an option to change playback speed

body:
# New "new" state

Problem: Before, we flagged an episode as *new* when several conditions where satisfied (not downloaded, not in the queue, not marked as played...). When a user wants an episode to not be flagged (e.g. to reset the feed counter showing the number of new episodes) she had to mark the feed as played.
Another problem showed when subscribing to a new podcast. We decided we only want to most recent episode to appear as new. To achieve that, we ourselves had to mark all other episodes as played. Users cannot distinguish if they actually played the episode or not.

Solution: New is now its own (database) state. Basically, "new" means unplayed "and some more". We no longer have to mark episodes as played on subscribing, they simply become unplayed. On the downside, we now have no mark new episodes as unplayed when they are added to the queue, downloaded, played and so on (on the other side, retrieving new episodes from the DB is a lot easier).

# Drawer feed preferences

Users can now customize the feed order and counter.

![hui](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/8507677/d2a84ad0-224c-11e5-84a0-5e62e0b92319.png)

Resolves #983

# Drawer feed context menu

Users can now mark all episodes as seen (all new episodes become unplayed) or as played (all new or unplayed...).

![0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/8507661/5f26acfa-224c-11e5-8a31-714541c77bb3.png)

Resolves #922


# Refactorings

I was fed up with all the stupid callbacks. So I took the upgrade DB code and moved it. Also renamed some occurences of read to played.

Also deleted the APSPDownloadAlgorithm and APSPCleanupAlgorithm classes. They are never used and belong to another project...
title: Drawer: Feed context menu, counter and order

body:
Obvious, visual change: When claimed media size is zero bytes, we no longer show "0 B", but nothing. I believe this is superior to showing "Unknown size" and alike, the user would not know why this is or what she can do to fix it.

For episodes, where the file size is unknown or suspiciously low (some feed seem to give the runtime in minutes...), we ask the server for the correct file size in a background service. This service is started when the app does the same (an old run may have been interrupted), but also when one or several feeds are refreshed.

This will fail if the server does not support the HEAD request method. As I have yet to encounter a server that does not, I was not able to find a workaround for this probably quite rare case.

Fixes #990
title: Get filesize from server

body:
As discussed in #441 

The feeds were changed from alphabetical to number of unplayed episodes. Is it possible to make it an option?

The two ways I use antennapod are affected by this:

1. Listening to podcasts on demand: me or a friend have a specific feed that we want to listen to, so we want to pull up the feed, see if there are any new episodes or old episodes that we haven't listened to.
2. Queuing up a small percentage of subscribed podcasts.  

I know some other people personally who are the same way.  Detail from my previous post:

I have a limited amount of time available to listen to podcasts compared to the amount of subjects and podcasts I'm interested in. Most of my feeds have a large amount of unplayed new episodes, but that tag is still useful to me:

1. Subscribe to a large list of podcasts of various subjects (from educational to comedy to career-specific)
2. Select a small amount of feeds to auto-download 
3. Add specific episodes to the queue (or for direct streaming) via description
4. Let queue auto-download when on wifi

Step 3 is of course what is affected by this:

 * "New Episodes" tab
   * mixes all the topics together
   * low-frequency feeds can get lost amongst higher-frequency feeds.
 * Static alphabetical view of podcast feeds
   * allows quick access by subject or feed
   * tagging may work as well as I saw in another thread, but one feed may be lighthearted or heavy on the same subject, where selecting individual feeds is still useful to me
   * Unplayed tag still useful (in case marking all as read sorts it alphabetically)
     * old unplayed podcasts are useful if I've exhausted my queue for that subject

I'm open to suggestions in a better process for the same use case with the update.

As the setting depends on your use case (which doesn't usually change), it should not be on the main UI, but rather somewhere in the settings, where I personally don't think it would be considered clutter.
title: Option to sort feeds alphabetically

body:
In #969 we updated DownloadService to return a copy of the list of downloads. That prevented the views from referencing data that wasn't there anymore.

However, I didn't set it to send a copy of that list every time the data changed.  Previously there was 'onDownloadDataAvailable' which would get called when the initial list was created and 'onContentChanged' which would get called whenever anything changed.  Now, there is just 'onContentChanged' and it takes the content itself.

This solves the remaining problems from #968, but it does so at a cost. Now, any time the download list changes we'll create a copy of it. When we're downloading a lot of small items (feeds for example) the list might change rapidly.  That means we'll be creating a lot of these objects, just for them to be garbage collected.

This seems to work fine on my Nexus One emulator, but I'd be curious to know if there's a better way.

title: IndexOutOfBoundsException in RunningDownloadsFragment

body:
This was reported for 1.2 and 1.3alpha.  It appears to be happening because of [this line](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/2d4705461c00dcb131b848789fa2a8a6021d19da/app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/adapter/DefaultActionButtonCallback.java#L104).

We get to this line only when the condition on [line 59](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/2d4705461c00dcb131b848789fa2a8a6021d19da/app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/adapter/DefaultActionButtonCallback.java#L59) is false, which means the episode has no media, but the GpodnetEpisodeAction.Builder is going to try to get the download URL for the 'media', which the item doesn't have (or we wouldn't have gotten here).

I think that we actually don't want to use Gpodder in this case. The user is never actually given a choice in this view to mark an episode with media as played. So this really shouldn't be present.  This mark as 'read' is really only for website only entries.  Which, means that the string used [here](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/blob/e1b494ba0577ce2cb60e6b3120e3534fb1f3211c/app/src/main/java/de/danoeh/antennapod/fragment/ItemFragment.java#L360) is probably wrong too.

body:
Let me repeat this again:
DO NOT PULL THIS AS-IS. THIS IS FOR DISCUSSION ONLY.

One of the features I still miss in AntennaPod is the ability to control the Auto Delete option *per feed*.
Some feeds are throwaway - once I hear them, I want them to be automatically delete.
Other feeds are precious and I want to keep the chapters I've downloaded.

This pull request adds a new 'Delete After Playback' spinner to the FeedInfoActivity. It has 3 states:
Default - use the global setting
Yes - delete after playback, regardless of the global settings
No - Do not delete after playback, regardless of the global settings

This is my first Android work, and I have a VERY shallow understanding of Java (I come from C/C++), so this pull request is based on googling stackoverflow and the SDK documentation.

I know for a fact that this code does NOT work yet. I ran it through the emulator and I see that my settings is not saved between invocations. I'm sending this to solicit feedback and to learn `android programming.

I also hope I didn't do anything stupid with git. There were a few commits on the main repository between the time I forked and the time I merged my changes back to create the pull request.

body:
In the feed view, you can now:
* Mark all as unplayed
* Download all unplayed
* Enqueue all unplayed

All of these will show a confirmation dialog just as "mark all as played" does.

This PR started with adding the ability to enqueue and download all unplayed episodes. Just downloading/enqueuing all episodes regardless of their play state seemed unreasonable to me.

When a new podcast/feed is added, all but one episodes are marked as played. To download/enqueue all episodes of a newly subscribed podcast, it became necessary to be able to undo this default behavior and mark all episodes as unplayed. 

![new](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/8307056/ced9ab4e-19bc-11e5-8376-ef19df967d32.png)

Resolves #871
Partially resolves #520

body:
Hi

If I wanted to implement continuous playback by default - NOT VIA THE QUEUE. User selects the latest podcast and plays it, when done it moves to the next item what would be the easiest way to do this?

We are creating an App with one podcast preloaded and preventing adding further. Adding to the queue does not make sense due to the nature of the audio, where some are 30 seconds and goes to the next item.

Forcing the user to put audio into a queue would have to be repeated each time they used the app.

So, on playing the latest it should move to the next item downwards.

Any ideas?
title: Question regarding continous playback

body:
Fixes AntennaPod/AntennaPod#942

PlaybackServiceMediaPlayer.getPSMPInfo() groups PlayerStatus and the currently playing media (Playable) in a synchronized method so that you can get a consistent picture at any one point in time as to what was happening.  Unfortunately, it was getting called in other synchronized methods (of another class) and PlaybackServiceMediaPlayer has other synchronized methods that also get called.  This occasionally results in deadlock.

To fix it, I created a non-synchronized getPlayable() and now call either getPlayerStatus or getPlayable depending on which is needed except for the rare circumstances when they are both needed. When they're both needed we still call getPSMPInfo().  Luckily, the case where we need both aren't the cases that were causing this deadlock, so I think this should solve the problem.

I would appreciate some review of these changes to make sure I didn't miss anything bad.
title: Only call getPSMPInfo if you need both the status and the playable.

body:
A user reported a deadlock via Google Play. 

After looking at the dump I think what's happening is this:
saveCurrentPosition is synchronized and calls PlaybackServiceMediaPlayer.getPSMPInfo() which is itself synchronized.  PlaybackServiceMediaPlayer.setPlayerStatus (which is synchronized) calls saveCurrentPosition. Since these things can happen from different threads we wind up with deadlock.

body:
AP keeps resurrecting (downloading and adding to the queue) episodes I have listened to.

The resurrected episodes get added as new ones come out in the same feed. At one point the queue was completely empty, the next day I had the new episodes released that day, plus the previous one for each of those feeds. I have auto refresh on every 4th hour, along with autodowload/queue. 

When long-pressing on the episodes I have the option to mark them as unplayed, so I'm assuming AP remembers I've listened to them, or marked them as played/skipped (difference?) before. Marking then as unplayed gives me the option to play them. All the files exist on the device and I can play them immediately and I don't have the option to stream them.

When I notice this, I have to go into each episode, tap to remove the file, wait for the file to be removed, tap to remove it from the queue, back out, wait a while until the episode disappears from the queue (takes several seconds, if it even works), and hope they don't come back again.
Sorting the queue while doing this can get really interesting as it randomly ressurrects episodes I just removed too.

I have a Samsung S3 GT-I9300 with Cyanogenmod 12.1 and I'm currently in the alpha/beta program.
title: Episode necromancy

body:
Now that AntennaPod isn't being maintained by @danieloeh any longer and a team of people are working on it, Daniel, mentioned that he felt we should change who the Flattr money goes to.

After discussing with Daniel and @mfietz we decided that we should remove the ability to flattr the app.  The reason being that since the team is split up, there's no one person who the money should go to.  At the moment we have no expenses (apart from time).  So there really isn't a great way to deal with the revenue Flattr was providing.

We are, of course, very pleased that people like the app enough to donate.  We just don't know how to deal with those funds justly, and as a result felt it would be better to remove the ability to Flattr AntennaPod directly.

This should resolve #507 and #567 as we just won't support accepting money any longer.  If people have a better idea of what to do, please share it here.
title: Remove button to Flattr AntennaPod

Furthermore, the bottom Now Playing/Play-pause bar shows the episode that just finished with the pause button.

How to replicate:

2. Put not downloaded podcast in Queue right below the previous one
3. Play first podcast
4. Go to playback controls and drag playback timer to end of file

6. Go back to Queue

When the podcast at the bottom of the Queue finishes playing, a message appears at the bottom saying "Item Removed           Undo" where pressing the Undo returns the podcast to the Queue. 
This only happens for the bottom Queue item, perhaps because for the others there is always a bar with play button for the next episode at the bottom.
Either this message should be removed entirely, or appear consistently at the end of every podcast, right now it seems like a built-in feature accidentally left on.

How to replicate:
1. Add podcast to Queue
2. Play it
3. Go to playback controls and drag time to end of podcast
4. AP goes back to Queue and shows "Item Removed" message.
title: Item Removed / Undo message at end of last podcast in Queue

body:
# Queue not opening

I start with the tricky bit: When the main activity is restarted or resumed, we open the last fragment the user opened. Until now, this was read and deleted (set null). When coming back from another activity (audio player), the last fragment would else (when not nulled) be read (this would be the same as the current one) and the current fragment would be loaded again (my emulator shows some sort of short flashing).

Setting the last fragment to null had the following consequence: Coming back from the audio activity, the last fragment would be read and set to null. Opening the other activity and going back would query the last fragment again, this time the preference would be null and the default value Queue would be returned. The app now believes the current fragment to be the queue and not open the queue when trying to do so via drawer. So far, so confusing...

To fix this, the main activity now stores the current fragment in a new string variable, the last fragment is no longer forgotten (nulled). When the last fragment is read, we now check if the last fragment is the current fragment (this can only be the case if the activity is resumed). If they are the same, there is nothing to be done.

Resolved #919 

# Scaling up a small cover 
![small_cover](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/8271363/adc6042a-1813-11e5-867c-738d73d5896b.png)

Resolves #921

# Long URL getting wrapping
![long_url](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/8271362/ab58e388-1813-11e5-8075-66697e0bf384.png)

Resolves #923
title: Fixes Queue not opening, small podcasts images not scaling up and long URL not wrapping

body:
Hi, I'm no contributer to AntennaPod, but simply a single user observing some issues with the newest version of AntennaPod. The update was done automatically within my Wiko Rainbow (Android 4.4.2) at 16.06.

First of all thank you for this marvellous piece of software. I'm that glad to have it as no other podcast-player on Android is that simple, minimalistic, stable and focused.

With the newest update from 16.06.2015 I observe a significant delay in displaying the episodes-lists, the played list, the podcasts themselves, etc.
The feature showing the unlistened episodes on the right side of the podcasts is great, however it looks like all the changes have changed the speed of the application overall.

Showing the playing list with 321 entries needs more than 20 seconds. Potentially a problem with the length of the list as after deletion of the playing list things are fine again.

However adding a podcast-episode to the playing list by using the context menu lasts ~10-15 seconds.

Opening a podcast-overview lasts 2-3 seconds. That's definitely longer than before. Not dramatic, but new.

But the most significant problem I observed first today having no internet connection at all. I have downloaded all the episodes and placed them in the playing list. Opening the playing list lasted approx. 40-50 seconds. Jumping back and opening one of the podcasts directly was not possible, no episodes were displayed. From my perspective AntennaPod seems to unusable if there's no internet connection even the episodes are downloaded. I could not observe this behaviour with the previously installed version.

Perhaps you can use these details for further improvement. With a heavy heart I will have to search for another podcast-player.

Ciao, Georg
title: Some remarks on the version released on 16.06.2015 (performance issues)

body:
We now store in the database if a media file has an embedded picture. In principle, this makes any further checking superfluous.

Migration: Already downloaded files are checked and the database is updated accordingly. While the files are processed, we show a progress dialog to the user. (This dialog will be shown in future database migration)

This branch is based on the similar hotfix.

Resolves #898
title: Store information if file has embedded picture in the database

body:
On my Nexus 4 and 7 (both running Cyanogenmod 12.1 nightly) I've noticed that downloading of feeds and episodes causes unusual high memory usage. It's increasing with the number of downloads in parallel but the used memory is not assigned to AntennaPod itself but seems to be used by the android system. While "system" is used to use around 300 MB on my Nexus 7 when idle, it's increasing to 750 MB while downloading 3 episodes and to more than 1.1 GB when downloading 10. Sometimes the used system memory stays at 800 MB, even after the downloads are finished and AntennaPod was killed using a task killer.

I could reproduce this behaviour after reinstalling (only imported my previously created OPML file). In Version 1.1.2 the memory usage is perfectly normal so I'm now back on this version.
title: Huge memory usage on AntennaPod 1.2

body:
Hi,
I have only recently begun to experiment with AntennaPod, but I like it so far. This is more of a question than a bug report maybe. I'm wondering about the skip button and the auto delete behavior.
I am on the Google play version 1.1.2 and I download episodes manually so far.
I understand that there's a cache where episodes go after I listened to them and the oldest gets deleted from there once it's full. Or do all episodes go there once I download them and they delete no matter whether I ever listened to them? Is there a way to list all episodes that I have currently downloaded? Does the cache only work with auto-downloading?

The auto-delete after playback option is in addition to the cache, isn't it?

https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/111 talks about a skip button in relation to auto-deleting. This is exactly the behavior that I am looking for. However, the skip button is just not there on my phone. Or I cannot spot it :)
The notification area only shows play / pause. What's the easiest way to get to the next episode? 

Kind regards,
Matthias Kauer

![screenshot_2015-06-16-09-33-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2436121/8174509/eed5c4b2-140f-11e5-88d2-5f27dadbef42.png)

body:
Resolves #854

I can only guess what exactly goes wrong here.
My guess is that okhttp either has a bug in its un-gzip and throws an error although the data was read correctly - or the server does not comply with some standard (e.g. there is no content-length field).

Catching the exception and just continuing as if nothing happened seems to work.

Not sure if additional checks would do any good. We could check the content length if it is sent by the server, but a lot of servers seem to get that wrong (sending the content length of the unzipped data)
title: Fixes "gzip finished without exhausting source" error

body:
When using prestissimo, AntennaPod crashes from time to time, either when the application is off for a long time, or when jumping to the next podcast (not 100% of the time, though. sometimes I do get to play 2 consecutive podcasts at x1.2, but most of the time it will fail when switching to the next one).

My default speeds are 1x and 1.2x. I usually listen to speech podcasts at 1.2x, and Music at 1x.

After a crash (sometimes the App stops, and sometime it just refuses to play), I need to do the following to get it back to work:
1. go to the Application list ("square" icon/button on Lollipop), and remove the app from the list.
2. Turn off the phone for a few seconds to ensure it's removed from memory.
3. turn on the phone and run the app again.
4. Try playing again. It will play for a brief time (< 1s) and then stop playing. however, it is still responsive and will let me press the prestissimo speed indication and set it back to 1.0
5. Repeat step (1) - (3) 
6. try playing again, this time it will play, but at 1x speed.
7. Wait a few seconds, then press the 1.0 to turn it into 1.2

This has been like this for a very long time, I'm not sure if it ever worked flawlessly.
title: Prestissimo-related crashes

body:
Running:
AntennaPod 1.1.2 on CyanogenMod CM11 M11 and a Galaxy S4.  AntennaPod is set up so that podcast episodes must be manually downloaded

Issue: 
If I have at least two new podcast episodes in my download list, downloading the 2nd after the first causing the error `unfortunately antennapod has stopped`  and AntennaPod to restart

If I have a number of new episodes, for example 3, available in my queue for downloads. 
  
  1. podcast1_e12
  2. podcast2_e05
  3. podcast3_e634

I start to download these new episodes first pressing the download icon for `podcast1_e12`.  The download begins, I then click the download icon for `podcast2_e05`.  As soon as I do this AntennaPod crashes/restarts with error `unfortunately antennapod has stopped`.  The crash is always on the 2nd podcast in the list and no others (largest sample to date is 4).

However if I try and download them in any other order than `1`, `2`, `3` the download works fine.

If I do it in any order other than `1`, `2`, `3` and then cancel all downloads I am then able to download in order `1`, `2`, `3` with out a crash.
title: Crash when downloading episodes manually in a particular order

body:
An item that has been deactivated and reactivated download won't be auto-downloaded.

How to reproduce this:
- Wait for an item to be downloading (or delete the download to force it).
- Cancel download. The app will disable auto-download for the item.
- Reenable auto-download for the item.
- Delete next downloaded episodes.
- Wait for download (or force it, by disabling and reenabling wifi).

Expected result: The reenabled item should download

Actual result: Following items would be downloaded instead

Version. 1.2 build 54.

body:
I ran in to a deadlock issue when testing 1.2 build 53 on my HTC One M7 running 5.0.2.

It started when playback was getting interrupted by navigation. Some of the interruptions worked and then eventually playback just never resumed.  Eventually I hooked it up to adb logcat and was able to see it generate the traces.txt file.

The entire time it was locked it was printing lots of these messages:
```
05-23 16:38:10.624: D/PlayerWidgetService(1653): Service was called while updating. Ignoring update request
```

I think this may be due to [this change](https://github.com/AntennaPod/AntennaPod/commit/fd30ec8189a1d9b47adfa31a9fe7dbc2085061f6#diff-28d8471f71a58338c63e08375776702aL537) where the tryLock() was changed to a lock(). 

[Here is a dump of the thread traces](https://gist.github.com/TomHennen/8c946d4ef0c72ae40b02)
title: Deadlock during playback in 1.2 alpha

I've installed the latest version 1.1.2 from the PlayStore on both my mobile phone and my tablet and recieve connection errors with some feeds and when trying to connect to gpodder.net over wifi. With gpodder the following error message appears:

java.net.SocketTimeoutException: failed to connect to gpodder.net/2605:2700:0:5::4713:9656 (port 443) after 30000ms

Many feeds are working fine, but for these I get a similar error message:

http://blog.ct.de/ctuplink/ctuplink.rss
https://netzpolitik.org/category/netzpolitik-podcast/feed/
http://stimmen.univie.ac.at/feed/mp3

The error messages always include IPv6 adresses and read like this

The error does only occur over wifi. When trying to connect to gpodder or downloading feeds via mobile data connections everything is working fine. The issue also had appeared in the last version by the way.

Thanks in advance!

All of this is open for discussion, some of the context menus might be too crowded... Now, they basically include any possible action that is not reachable within one click (thing: no button for it)


# New "new"

New no longer means unread/unplayed. It still has to be unread, but additionally
* Not in the queue
* Media not downloaded
* Not paused (partially played)

An item can become read, if it is marked as read, it is completely played or it smart mark as played is activated and the threshold is reached.


# Nav draver indicators

![failed-indicator](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/7572098/290403ca-f81c-11e4-9b78-18e4df4d4b55.png)

* Indicator when a feed refresh failed
* Number of unread episodes per feed
* Feeds are ordered by the number of unplayed episodes


# FeedItem context

![itemlist-context](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/7572140/64ca321c-f81c-11e4-8a9e-9b062e4bc00b.png)

body:
Hi `AntennaPod` developers, I'm a Ph.D. student and doing research on Android async programming, particularly on AsyncTask and IntentService. AsyncTask can lead to memory leak and losing task result when GUI is recreated during task running (such as orientation change). [This article](http://bon-app-etit.blogspot.com/2013/04/the-dark-side-of-asynctask.html) describes the problems very well. 

We discussed with some Android experts and they agree with this issue, and claim that AsyncTask can be considered only for short tasks (less than 1 second). However, using IntentService (or AsyncTaskLoader) can avoid such problems since their lifecycles are independent from `Activity`/`Fragment`.

In `AntennaPod `, many of the AsyncTasks are declared as non-static inner classes of `Activity`/`Fragment`. So the above issue can occur (especially for relatively long tasks).

I refactored 8 AsyncTasks in `AntennaPod ` to IntentService (in separate commits), with the help of a refactoring tool we developed. I also mark some types as `Serializable` in order to put them into Intent. Do you think using IntentService should be better in some of these 8 scenario? Do you want to merge (some) commits in this pr? Thanks.
title: Convert AsyncTasks to IntentService

* Creates a new field boolean auto_download field in the DB's FeedItem model (default: true).
* When the user cancels a (manual or automatic) download, this field is set to false.

* Refactoring of the Auto Download algorithm. When IDs are provided, don't read all  items that are queued or unread and filter by ID, pull items with an acceptable ID from the database directly.

This basically means that the events provided to onScroll are null. From onScroll:
```
public boolean onScroll(MotionEvent e1, MotionEvent e2, float distanceX, float distanceY) {

        final int x1 = (int) e1.getX();   // this is line 381
        final int y1 = (int) e1.getY();
        final int x2 = (int) e2.getX();
        final int y2 = (int) e2.getY();
```

I don't think this is DSLV's 'fault', but it should be easy enough to fix.
title: NullPointerException in DragSortController.onScroll

* Drawer preference (all of the lists can be hidden, this is the fallback)
* Restore last fragment (lists and feeds)
* Fragments are referred by their tag (lists) or their (feed) id
* Drawer dialog UI tests
* UI optimizations
title: Nav Drawer Preferences

body:
It can make a mess of the crash reports. Yes, if we keep the mapping we could reproduce them.

But is there any upside to obfuscating? We're an open source application. There's no IP to protect?

I'm considering adding ``` -dontobfuscate ``` to proguard.cfg. 

Are there any reasons I shouldn't?

(see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9651703/using-proguard-with-android-without-obfuscation for some potential problems and a solution)
title: Don't obfuscate with ProGuard

body: Branch was not up to date. Luckily, only small commits.
title: Merge v1.1.1 -> develop (v2)

body:
These were happening on some handsets when onPrepareOptionsMenu was getting called.

It is sometimes called before the menu is actually loaded, causing us to not find the
MenuItem we're looking for.

This solves the symptom, if not the cause.

After making this change the number of failures reported on Apkudo dropped from 20 devices to just 6.
title: Fixed some NullPointerExceptions

body:
When a phone call is received via a Bluetooth headset and 'Pause for interruptions' is set in the settings, the podcast playback stops correctly, but never resumes when the phone call ends.

When on the other hand, it is interrupted by GPS navigation messages (e.g. Waze), it correctly resumes playing the podcast.

I din't think it is relevant, but 'Headphone' disconnect and 'Headphone reconnect' are also enabled.
title: AntennaPod fails to resume after a phone call

body:
It would be nice if we prominently indicated which feeds failed to refresh. You can probably get this from the download log but something more in your face would be nice. An indicator on the Podcast itself in the Nav drawer perhaps?

Taken from a play store comment:

> Stopped showing new podcasts Used to be good, but won't show which podcasts it has failed to refresh. Podcast Addict doesn't have this problem so will be using that from now on. Update: The app will not show me which podcasts have failed or succeeded to download. Podcast Addict shows that certain podcasts have new content, this app does not right now.
title: Should indicate which Feeds failed to refresh
updating build number for 1.1.1 alpha test

body:
I recently uploaded a release candidate of 1.1.1 to the Alpha channel for testing (you can also find it here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/7dyg37vi34gqunu/AntennaPod_1.1.1_release.apk?dl=0).

This resolves some issues that were reported by users who missed the All Episodes view and used it instead of the Queue.

All things considered this is a fairly minor change. But some feedback would be welcome before we push it out to production.

Are there any other immediate changes we should include in 1.1.1?  My hope is to get this out quickly to help out folks that are currently broken, but if anything is missing and straightforward we could include it now (or in a 1.1.2).

Changelog:
Version 1.1.1
------------------
* All Episodes and New Episodes are now both present
* Remembers which activity was last active instead of always going to the Queue
* When adding a podcast the most recent episode is considered 'new'
title: Release 1.1.1 needs testing

body:
From Google Play
```
Can't see downloaded episodes Why did you remove the All Podcasts list? Once a podcast is downloaded, it is removed from the New Podcast list, and not added to my queue. Its hard to see what podcasts I have to listen to.
```

So I wouldn't worry much about this, except that they say the that after the episode is downloaded it doesn't show up in the Queue.  My guess is that they don't have auto add enabled. But that's definitely not good behavior. Once #748 is published his overall issue should go away, but the queue, at least for him, isn't working the way it should. We should take a look at this.

Sometimes I would like to control the order of episodes displayed. I might want to listen to the podcast from the first. Right now, I have to scroll all the way down to play each episode and this is especially a problem if there are a lot of episodes in the podcast. 

Could there be an option to control the order of podcasts by "Date-Added" or so on?

body:
Initial PR to have both 'All Episodes' and 'New Episodes'.

We might want to choose a different icon for All Episodes. We currently use the Queue icon (was better than New Episodes).

This helps resolve #741 and #742.  It also resolves some of the issues we were having with swiping to mark items as read when the user was view all the episodes. Currently the user can't swipe to mark things as read in the All Episodes view.

![All and New Episodes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5216560/7172510/1f7a1c64-e3b7-11e4-9a25-441c8f77cd06.png)

body:
I think we missed a major use case of 'All Episodes'

From a recent play store review:
```
All episodes listing removed No clue why it was removed, now I have to look at a list with barely visible episodes. The old listing was far better. Showed episodes and clearly showed what was new. Silly change for the sake of change. Nothing beneficial.
```

The user from #741 also seemed to care quite a bit about 'All Episodes'.

I think some users (not sure how many) weren't actually using the queue. They were just using All Episodes and playing things as they wished.  Our changes disrupted their workflow significantly.  We didn't notice this because we all play everything from the queue and thought of 'All Episodes' as a place to go simply to add things to the Queue.

I'd like to suggest the following changes for a 1.1.1 release (based on the version_1.1 branch):
* Instead of defaulting to the Queue view, we should really just display the last fragment the user was looking at when the app closed
* We should probably decrease or remove the amount of fading that happens to 'read' episodes in the 'New Episodes' list
* We should see if there are any low risk ways to implement some of @heckler01's suggestions from #721 (if there's no easy way it can wait for a more major update)

Thoughts?
title: Major missed use case: Managing everything from 'All Episodes'

body:
I had a discussion with someone on the Google Group for AntennaPod.  I'm not quite sure why they're experiencing the issues they're seeing. If it's something to do with the device they're using or if this is a usability issue or some combination of the two.  He seems frustrated enough that we should probably consider what is going on and think about how it could be addressed.  I'm following up with the author to find out what device they're using.

Tim:
```
Sad enough that you had to switch from the play list to "all episodes" every time you launch the app for a few months now, the "all episodes" lists is now missing completely. If I want to listen to an episode now, I have to search 3 lists to find it. This makes this great app almost unusable. Additionally, you have to scroll very, very carefully now not to swype one of the episodes out of the list.
Please bring back the "all episodes" list or at least have a switch in the settings to turn it on. I was so glad I found a good podcast app, finally, I don't want to move all my podcasts again.
```

Me:
```
Hi Tim,

The All Episodes list is still around, it's just called 'New Episodes'.  'New Episodes' defaults to showing only those episodes that haven't been added to the queue.  However, you can click the little three dots and clear the option that says to show new episodes only.

I wonder if you're using the app in a way that is somehow different from how most other people are using it.  Most people add episodes to the queue and listen to them from there.  You can configure the app to do this for you automatically if you like.
```

Tim
```
Thanks for your answer. I tried to use the app the way you proposed now and add the episodes I want to listen to to the playlist, but this release seems to be extremely buggy. E.g.
- Some of my podcasts were in the playlist, some are not, I could not figure out what rule is behind this. So I decided to start from scracht und delete the episodes in the playlist to start with an empty one and add the episodes I plan to listen to. A few seconds after I emptied the list, more and more seemingly random episodes appeared in the list again. If I swype episodes away from the playlist, these exact same episode appear again in the list (happened 4 times with one episode) after a few seconds or minutes. The list is constantly filled up with random episodes - and the app seems to start downloading these random episodes after adding them to the list.
- If "swyping away" multiple episodes in a row, the app reproducibly crases
- Some of my podcasts are automatically downloaded, some are not, even though I have "automatic download" enabled for all podcasts (but this problem also existed in previous releases)
- If I download podcasts manually in the "new eposodes" list, they are not marked as downloaded after the download (at least in 90% of the cases) - so I don't know which one I already downloaded
- As already said, swyping is much more sensive than in any other app, which always makes you swype episodes away when scolling. Undoing the operation does not bring back the episode, at least not until changing to another list and then opening the first list again.
- Loading the list sometimes takes minutes - or maybe the process hangs somehow. I never experienced that with the previous releases.

Maybe going back to the last stable release and fixing the bugs beforde publishing the new release would be a good idea. I really appreciate the work you do for a good, free opensource app, but on my part I cannot really use the app in this condition.
```

Me:
```
Hmm. We honestly haven't had those problems (crashes, random downloads, etc...) and have received mostly positive feedback regarding this release.

However, I'm certainly concerned. I'll be sure to relay these concerns to the rest of the team and we'll see what we can do.
```
title: Issues Reported from Google Groups "Please(!) bring back the "all episodes" list"

body:
Specifically PlaybackTests. startLocalPlaybackFromQueue and PlaybackTests. startLocalPlayback are failing.

They're failing because they expect the AudioplayerActivity to show up after you click on 'Play' from within 'New Episodes' and 'Queue'.  That isn't happening anymore.  I don't know when this change was introduced, if it was intentional or inadvertent (if I had to guess I'd say it was #693).

I think that, before we make any change, we should figure out what the behavior *should* be.  Do we want the audio player activity to start when you click on 'play' on an item in the list?  I'm not sure that makes sense.

Any opinions?

body:
I have a site which is fully protected by HTTP Basic Auth. When users try to add the feed in AntennaPod, they are prompted for the password twice, even though both the website and the feed are on the same domain and use the same HTTP Basic Auth realm.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add the following site to AntennaPod: http://p.j-crew.de
2. Enter the username and password (both are "a", without the quotes)
3. Confirm the RSS feed (there is only one)

Expected result:
The password from step 2 above is remembered and used for the feed and for downloading the MP3 files.

Actual result:
The user is queried again for the password after selecting the feed.

Further information:
The apache logs can be seen live at http://misc.j-crew.de/p-access.log and http://misc.j-crew.de/p-error.log (to see exactly which URLs were queried). There is an identical site except without HTTP Basic Auth at http://q.j-crew.de for comparison (with logs at http://misc.j-crew.de/q-access.log and http://misc.j-crew.de/q-error.log).
title: When discovering xml feed, password is not remembered

body:
Some thoughts about how the navigation drawer could be re-designed. Of course, some ideas might not be completely thought through - Feedback and ideas are appreciated. Basically, I think we should get rid of the Playback history and Downloads in its current form. In order: * New episodes: This is already changed in the current build, no further changes required. Think "Inbox". * Queue/Playlist: No changes. If requested, we could also have several Playlists. Feeds might get linked to a specific Playlist where new episodes would be added.
Episodes would not get added to "the queue", but rather "Add to [default playlist]" and "Add to..." (Opens dialog where user can choose playlist, if there a more than one).
Playlists could get renamed and episodes could be moved from one to the other. * Downloads: Should behave like an "Download folder". Will show any episodes currently downloaded to the device. Will have the ability to play and delete episodes. Sorting criteria could include publication date, file size, progress, "last usage" and more. * Favorites: Would only be displayed if the user actually marked episodes as favorites (yet to be implemented). Actions would basically be the same as Downloads. Being a favorite episode would also be considered when cleaning the cache to download new episodes. * Add podcast: No changes. Maybe some small visual changes.
+++ * Feeds: No changes.
+++ * Settings: no changes.
title: Navigation drawer re-design
