body:
Version 1.1 is about to be released. Some pretty significant changes were made and we'd like to make sure no problems have been introduced.

It would really help if people could test the current release build, either by joining the AntennaPod Alpha Google Plus group (https://plus.google.com/communities/117446128636140585144) or by just downloading the latest release build here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/4c475h3yst0ys38/AntennaPod-develop-current-release.apk?dl=0

Please report any new bugs that you encounter.

As many of you know @danieloeh stopped maintaining the project with 1.0.  I'm trying my best to maintain the project properly.  If you see that I'm doing anything wrong please let me know.  I'd like to thank @mfietz for all the hard works he's put in to fixing bugs and adding new features.  He's probably responsible for 70-80% of the changes you'll see in version 1.1.  Of course, a big thanks to everyone else that's contributed for this release, their changes have provided some great new features and fixes.

Going forward, if anyone would like to contribute, the most valuable thing for me would be if you could build the proposed pull requests and test the functionality introduced in that request. If you encounter any problems or have any suggestions, just add a comment to the PR.  If everything works well, please comment saying that everything works well. That will give me more confidence when merging the requests.

Thanks everyone!

![ff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/7007616/f7768f40-dc8b-11e4-8773-ed7bcb829c7b.png)

Users set fast forward and rewind time separately. This is set on the audio player activity by long pressing fast forward or rewind. Small numbers above the buttons show the current values.

The former preference setting has been removed.

FF/Rev seems to cause troubles on older devices. The seekbar is not updated properly when seeking while the audio is paused - the position is updated properly.
Until now, seeking was only possible when the audio was actually playing. On newer devices, the seekbar is not updated properly in very rare cases. Most of the time, it works as intended.

Closes AntennaPod/AntennaPod#642

(For easier review, I tried to add all tedious stuff into the first commit.)
title: Separate fast forward and rewind times

Episode actions are recorded and synced when user is logged into gpodder.

* Create episode actions when episodes are downloaded, played, deleted and marked as read
* Sync (download and upload) episode actions
* MediaPlayerActivity deletes almost completely played episode on close
* Improved parsing of datetime strings

![Screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6860662/6952930/3abeb508-d8c6-11e4-9eaf-aeb4c69f92c8.png)

## For debugging
You can goto https://gpodder.net/share/ and click the world icon near User page. Recently played doesn't seem to update immediately... Maybe the web server is caching the request

What I usually do:
$ curl -i -u [Username]:[Password] -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Accept: application/json" -X GET https://gpodder.net/api/2/episodes/[Username].json?since=[Timestamp]

Timestamp is seconds since 1.1.1970, set it to 0 or get the current time from http://www.epochconverter.com/ (For debugging, I take the current time and set the last three digits to zero).
You should see some nice JSON ;)

You should also see the syncing in logcat

body:
In the menu you can set a fast forward/backward step width between 5 and 60 seconds. This value will be applied on both, forward and backward.

The most frequent use cases for fast forward/backward are (in my opinion/experience):
* you want to skip some less interesting passage and find a point to continue listening
* you want to repeat a passage of about the last minute, maybe you have not listened to concentrated enough and and you must find the exact starting point again

For both use cases an unsymmetric forward/backward step size which allows you to step forward coarse and find the exact point stepping backward fine.

For example Linux Totem Video Player uses this technique with fixed step sizes of +60s / -15s. It is very easy to find a desired point by this means.

My suggestion is to gives the possibility to selcet forward/backward step widths independantly by providing:
* separate inputs for both values - or - 
* an input for fast forward and an extra multiplier for backward ratio: 0.1 / 0.25 / 0.5 / 1 (optional additionally: 2 / 4 / 10)
title: Enhancement: Unsymmetric fast forward/backward

body:
On older devices, crucial intermediate certificates are missing. In
this fix, we create a custom trustmanager. The algorithm follows the
certificate chain and checks validity and issuer signature. In the last
step, we take the root CA's certificate from the system's keystore and
verify the chain's last certificate thus validating the whole chain.

Fixes AntennaPod/AntennaPod/issues/576
title: make gpodder service usable for older devices again

I added [Design Time Attributes][dta] which are useful to **render meaningful previews** for the layout files in Android Studio. They also help to optimize layout in general. Further you can **add placeholders** for text and image elements. I use strong **background colors** for text fields and image views to preview their exact dimensions and margins.
None of these changes affects the compiled application code.

Here is an extreme example for *layout/downloadlog_item.xml*:

## Preview without Design Time Attributes

![antennapod-download-before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/144518/5891052/fc2e8bea-a47e-11e4-9f2f-08688b52c671.png)

## Preview with Design Time Attributes

![antennapod-download-improved](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/144518/5891054/00dc547e-a47f-11e4-87f2-ef340384c2cc.png)




[dta]: http://tools.android.com/tips/layout-designtime-attributes
title: Use design time attributes to assist layouting and value preview.

body:
Consider the following use case:

* User is subscribed to a number of podcasts
* User's queue is full with previously downloaded podcasts
* All the episodes in the queue are stale. The user doesn't want to listen to them (they already listened to them, they got behind, whatever).

With the current model the user would have to manually remove all the episodes from the queue, one by one. That can be very time consuming and tedious with a long queue.

If there were a 'empty queue' or 'clear queue' command the user could issue that command, all the episodes in the queue would be removed and then, when the system auto-updates, the queue would be filled with the latest episodes from their various subscriptions.

Worthwhile?
title: Add an 'Empty Queue' command

body:
By default I think the 'Queue' should be the first screen the user sees and not 'All Episodes'. The rational is that the user came in to the app for the most common operation: listening to podcasts.  Putting them in 'All Episodes' first makes them take an extra couple of steps to get to what they really want.

I could see only defaulting to Queue if there are actually episodes in the queue.

Thoughts?
title: Queue should be the default screen, not All Episodes

AntennaPod seems to construct the following filename for every episode: "Echo der Welt - Das Auslandsmagazin.mp3". The download links are in the form of e.g. "http://media.ndr.de/download/podcasts/podcast2988/AU-20141212-1609-3442.mp3".

title: Generated filename is the same for every episode and therefore episodes are overwritten

body:
Apparently AntennaPod stores audio files using the episode title as the filename (as opposed to using the original filename from the URL).  If the episode title is too long then it is not possible to download the episode due to a filesystem limitation -- it can still be streamed though.

The typical [limit](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_file_systems#Limits) for a filename on common filesystems is 255 bytes.
title: IOError: ENAMETOOLONG when downloading episode with long title

body:
One of Android 5.0 APIs is the Media playback. Quoting from here, http://developer.android.com/about/versions/android-5.0.html,
"If you are implementing notifications that present media playback status or transport controls, consider using the new Notification.MediaStyle template instead of a custom RemoteViews.RemoteView object. Whichever approach you choose, make sure to set the notification's visibility to VISIBILITY_PUBLIC so that your controls are accessible from the lock screen. Note that beginning in Android 5.0, the system no longer shows RemoteControlClient objects on the lock screen. For more information, see If your app uses RemoteControlClient."

Notification.MediaStyle can be found here: http://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Notification.MediaStyle.html

Unfortunately, the solution provided in Issue #405 doesn't seem like it will be supported in Android 5.0 and on.
title: Persistent notification and lockscreen controls for Android 5.0

4. Podcast 3 - Season 1 - Episode 2
5. Podcast 3 - Season 1 - Episode 3

8. Podcast 3 - Season 2 - Episode 1
9. Podcast 3 - Season 2 - Episode 2
10. Podcast 3 - Season 2 - Episode 3
11. Podcast 3 - Season 2 - Episode 4

Hey, first off, love AntennaPod. Just have been having some weird issues that seem to be independent of any updates to the app or Android. As far as I can tell, they appeared out of nowhere. The biggest issue is that pushing the play button next to a podcast in the queue no longer plays the podcast. instead, it takes me to the playback screen of the currently playing podcast (which remains paused). I can push the play button in the queue repeatedly and sometimes after a few presses it will take me to the playback screen and I can hit play again and the cast plays, but sometimes it can be upwards of 20 presses. If there is not a podcast currently playing then I can switch to any other podcast. Sometimes I will get an playback error message and then the playback screen will come up empty and I can play a new podcast then.

Another (I'm guessing) related issue is that continuous playback is checked but when a podcast ends and a new one loads, it does not play automatically. Continuous playback is checked in the setttings. 

I'm running version 0.9.9.3 on a Republic Wireless Moto X running Android 4.4.2
title: Playback/Queue problems

body: The log in the "Downloads" section appears to keep every download (successful and failed) forever. It would be great to be able to clear the log since it's getting very long.

I have the following packages installed:
Android SDK Tools 23.0.2
Android SDK Platform-tools 20
Android SDK Build-tools 20

```
Execution failed for task ':preBuild'.
```

Installing SDK Platform 19.3 (alongside 20.1) then gives the error

body:
Hi,
after the 0.9.9.0 release with the new UI became available on F-Droid I was finally able to test the new UI. Some feedback from my perspective:

- I like that there is finally a view that shows all downloaded items.
- Great that play list manipulation (moving up/down etc.) is much easier now. I seem to accidentally swipe off episodes too easily, but that may be just my clumsy fingers. Deletion on long press or context menu or so might be safer.
- Please bring back display of playing time and possibly release date and podcast name to items in the playlist. This seems to be only available in the Downloads/Finished view. Release date and podcast name should at least be avaibale from the episode detail view. But playing time is quite essential for me.
- One thing that feels really completely wrong is that in the All Episodes view, when trying to scroll up from the top of the list, a refresh of all podcasts is triggered. This alone makes this view completely unusable for me. Please note that this process can take quite some time and it seems that other parts (Playlist etc.) are not accessible at all. (I have a lot of podcasts and not the fastest device on the market.) IMO it should only be triggered explicitly and not accidentally when scrolling a list where one even cannot see whether one is at the top of the list or not. Even worse as when entering the app from the widget and clicking in the upper left of the player one ends up automatically in this view. Also there is the refresh button in the upper right, why should one be able to trigger this in another way? 

Anyway, please keep up the good work and thanks for releasing the software for free.

Edit: It would also be great if the number of contained episodes would be visible again at the top of the list as before.
title: New UI: Some feedback

body: Seeing 2012 made me wonder if the app was stale the first time I opened the about page.  Users should feel great about an app with this much development activity.

body:
I have a whole bunch of podcasts in my AntennaPod with some of them being feeds from radio stations, which generate a lot episodes (several per day) and where I'm only interested in single episodes. Every other day (like once a week or so) I browse through all the podcasts I have in my list and add the episodes I'm interested in to my playlist.

This is of course easiest done by selecting one source and going to all the new tracks there and then proceed with the next source. Therefore I then end up with a playlist that has the tracks in the order in which I have added them, i.e. with lets say 5 tracks from radio station *A* then two from station *B* and so on.

Especially with topics that are currently in the news it would be convenient if there was an option to sort the tracks chronologically by their release date. For example a menu (maybe also with other sort orders) in the "organize playlist" view could do that.
title: Option to sort episodes in playlist by release date

body:
I really like the new UI, but more than how it looks I am concerned about how it works. I am hoping to be able to have AntennaPod work like this: 

All new episodes are downloaded immediately, not with the next refresh like it is today. I also want all new episodes automatically to be added the the queue. And finally I would like to either be able to set which screen it opens to (Queue or New Episodes) or that it opens to the screen you had open when you closed it. I would like new episodes added to the top of the queue by default (at least as an options also. Finally I want episodes automatically deleted when they are played although I can live with the current episode cache method of limited storage use by AntennaPod.


How happy should I be with the new UI in this regard, or are the things I am talking about not part of the redesign?
title: The new UI.

body:
I have made some significant changes to the user interface of the app over the last few weeks, which are going to be published in the next version of AntennaPod. But i would like to make sure that the new interface works reliably and without any major bugs. So it would be awesome if the people who are using the nightly builds anyway or would like to support the development of the app could download the [Test APK](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/45vgg13bmh8jmhp/AAAQGpUiQGdnU9852CRAPslYa/antennapod-newgui-583361b-nightly.apk) from the nightly builds folder to see if it runs on their device. 
Please note that, while the test version should be quite usable at this point, there might still be bugs that only occur on certain devices or with certain podcast subscribtions and therefore haven't been found yet.

If you find any bugs, you can post them in this issue. Please don't forget to add the version number of your Android device.

Thanks!

![device-2014-04-27-000619](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/968613/2809953/5ea21700-cd8f-11e3-906f-05eae83553fe.png)
title: New user interface needs testing

body:
So, apparently the newest version downloads episode pictures. My issue is that most of my podcast provide an image for each episode (although it's apparently always just the logo/image of the podcast itself) and with some feeds containing 100+ or even 300+ episodes, I now have an "images" folder with 100+mb of completely useless copies of a few podcast images, and that was _after_ I quit the update by force-closing the app halfway through.

One example is "Stop Podcasting Yourself".. over 300 episodes and each one has a 500kb 1400x1400px jpg file. So the images from that podcast alone would use up ~150mb on my phone. And that's just one podcast. It's the most egregious example, but it's a problem with many feeds. Judge John Hodgman for example..150x152kb. Especially for people with limited data, actually doing that first refresh with the newest version can really screw you over (luckily I was on wifi). But even then, 100-200mb for pointless episode images is a waste considering the limited storage on most phones.

Additionally it seems like a download queue of 1000+ can crash the app.

There needs to be a way to deal with this and imho it shouldn't be default behavior, especially not on mobile data.
title: impossible to disable downloading of episode images

body:
I'm working off the develop branch, fetched two hours ago. Normally I wouldn't write a bug report about the develop branch, but considering you merged it to the master branch 6 hours ago, I think it's fine.

To reproduce this
1. Have an empty queue
2. Go the podcasts tab and play something directly from the list (so without adding anything to the queue).
3. Finish the episode (doesn't matter how: skip, slide, listen)
4. Repeat 2, but make sure it's the same episode
4a. Notice that you can't play the episode.
4b. Notice that the episode is now in the queue, but can't play it from there either
4c. Remove and repeat 4 will result in the same situation.

How to get out of this situation (sometimes)
1. Play a different episode
2. Finish the episode (doesn't matter how: skip, slide, listen)
3. The app should skip to the next episode
4. Sometimes you can play this, sometimes you can't, but when you can and the episode finishes, things will go back to normal.
title: Playback and queue corrupts when an episode that was played outside of the queue finishes.

body:
Hey Daniel,

i had an problem to download files embedded in the feed were the url is already urlencoded. 

Reproduce the Problem:

1. add a new Podcast the "Android Developers Backstage" Podcast from gpodder.net
2. try to download an episode from this podcast
3. the Download failed with a 404

The Problem is in [src/de/danoeh/antennapod/service/download/HttpDownloader.java#L32](https://github.com/danieloeh/AntennaPod/blob/master/src/de/danoeh/antennapod/service/download/HttpDownloader.java#L32)

You first create an URL and after that you are creating an URI with all the components of this created URL. By using the multi-argument constructor URI the path of the URL get urlencoded again.
See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4858108/url-to-uri-encoding-changes-a-3d-to-253d for details

regards,
David
title: Fix url path get encoded twice

body:
My officemate just installed AntennaPod from F-Droid and was attempting to add the podcasts he listens to. He stumbled on:

http://www.cbc.ca/podcasting/includes/whitecoat.xml

"Parser Exception: At line 31, column 54: not well-formed (invalid token).

So, it's definitely an error with the feed. However, some RSS readers (for example, ownCloud News) _do_ parse it, XML error and all. Could some less harsh handling be added so that such podcasts could at least be added, or the error mitigated to some degree?

In this specific case, the error seems to be the & (rather than &) in "Leslee Thompson is the president & CEO of Kingston General Hospital", which is enclosed withing a <description> tag; WebKit throws up the error "xmlParseEntityRef: no name" for that. Would it be possible to just ignore such malformed entities if they're within a description or title tag?
title: Handling of bad XML?

body:
Following the principal of not having a user option if the author or software can choose for you, I suggest removing the "Headphones disconnect" option, and acting as if it is always ticked. In other words, make the app always pause when the headphones are removed without giving the user the choice to make the app behave otherwise.

My reasoning is that almost all users will have this option ticked already, making the option redundant and just taking up space in the Settings screen. I cannot see any reason why anyone would want playback to continue when headphones are removed. If for some reason someone wanted to share a good bit of a podcast with a wider audience, they could just press the play button after they remove the headphones.
title: Remove option regarding headphone disconnect, act as if always ticked

body:
When the automatic download updates the feeds and a new episode is found, that episode is not downloaded immediately. Instead AntennaPod will wait for your custom set update interval (2h in my case).

Leaving the house with an undownloaded episode is a bit annoying, easpecially when the download would have only taken a few seconds on your wifi.

I did not test if that issue appears when setting a high update interval, but if it does one would receive all new episodes only after a high delay.

My personal fix is to regularly check for new podcasts and hitting the update button manully, but I would like AntennaPod to be purely push- and not pull-style.
title: Auto downloading doesn't download new podcasts immediately but waits for the next interval

body:
Whenever I ask AntennaPod to download an episode, it force closes. The crashes used to only happen when downloading everything in my queue, but now it crashes even when I request an individual episode to be downloaded. If I increase the number of episodes allowed in my cache, I can then download specific episodes for a few days and then it starts force closing again.

I suspect this is caused by two inter-related issues.
* When the episode cache is full, it force closes instead of cancelling the download and providing some intelligent message to the user
* It appears not clean up download episodes after listening to them. I recently cleared dozens of old episodes out of my media folder that were not deleted when I completed listening to them. I suspect that some counter was not cleared when I deleted the files, so the application still thinks I'm at my limit of cached episodes.

AntennaPod 0.9.7.4
Nexus 4, Build JWR66V
title: Force close when downloading an episode

body:
This implements a queue of pending things to flattr (similar to #203 but implemented in a slightly different fashion) and adds support for automatic flattring of played episodes as requested in #87.

The workflow for the user is:
- if autoflattr is enabled, whenever 80% of an episode have been played it is added to the flattr queue (and a toast is displayed)
- manual flattring is done directly (flattring things in the queue along the way) if there is an internet connection. Otherwise the thing is added to the queue.
- when the feeds are updated, things in the queue are flattred (presumably there is an internet connection at that point), an android notification is displayed. Also at that point the flattr status of things is updated from the flattr API

Database changes:
- new column flattr_status for the feed and feeditem tables containing the timestamp when the thing was last flattrd. This value is updated when antennapod flattrs, as well as based on data from the flattr API whenever the feeds are refreshed. The latter may not be 100% reliable as the URL antennapod gets from the feed is not necessarily exactly the one recorded by flattr and returned by their API. I implemented some URI normalization that catches the corner cases I have encountered, there may be more. Also the flattr api does not return information on flattrability (i.e. things that were flattrd last month), so this is done in Antennapod.

I have considered implementing the flattr queue as a list of URLs to flattr as you suggested in #203, but I think it would be a lot more work (i.e. one would have to walk through the entire queue and the list of things that have been flattrd just in order to determine if an item is flattrable (and the corresponding menu item should be shown, as well as in order to avoid trying to flattr things multiple times), similarly to retrieve the feed titles of the things flattrd for showing in the notification). 

- new column played_duration for the feedmedia table containing for how long an episode has been played (this is the accumulated play time, *not* the current play position in the episode)
title: Flattr queue autoflattr

body:
The problem was that audioManager.abandonAudioFocus() was being called
before remoteControlClient.setPlaybackState(). That seems to have
prevented the BTC450 from knowing that the audio was paused. As a
result, the BTC450 continued to send "pause" instead of "play" for
subsequent button presses. The fix just moves the call to
abandonAudioFocus() until after setPlaybackState() has been called.
title: Fixes issue #249 (Cannot use Kinivo BTC450 bluetooth car kit to play after pause).

body:
I noticed that automatic feed refreshes for the ~ 50 feeds I subscribed to can take up to around 20 minutes when the device is asleep, in contrast to less than a minute when the device is awake.

This is happening because AntennaPod fails to hold a WakeLock while it is refreshing feeds or downloading media files. As a consequence, after the ```FeedUpdateReceiver```'s ```onReceive()``` method returns, the device will go back to sleep, although the actual downloads are still pending.
title: Automatic feed updates are slow when device is asleep

Here is a way to crash AntennaPod 100% of the time:

2. Quit AP (completely, either by killing the process or by rebooting the device).
3. Move the file

One workaround is to put back the file, but it may not be possible in some cases. Example: someone gives you a SD card, you listen to some music or podcast. Then you turn off the phone to give back the SD card, when you start AP again you have no way to prevent it from crashing.
Tested on my smartphone with Android 4.1.2.

body:
These two patches implement a queue for pending flattrs whenever no internet connection is available. All pending items are flattred when the next thing is flattred and an internet connection is available.

I would consider this a first step towards implementing danieloeh/AntennaPod#87

The second patch creates a new flattr_queue table in the database and uses it to store the items to be flattred. This bumps the DATABASE_VERSION to 9.

Items in the table (CREATE TABLE FlattrQueue (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, feedItem INTEGER, feed INTEGER)) may either be a pending flattr to a feedItem (feedItem nonzero, feed is ignored), a feed (feeditem must be zero/NULL) or to AntennaPod itself (both feedItem and feed are zero).
title: Flattr queue

body:
Adding variable speed playback to the service.  This doesn't include any GUI functionality yet, as I feel like how that is implemented could be a bit more contentious.  I'll (or somebody else can) add that separately.

Explanation of changes:
The com.aocate stuff is a Presto client library that reimplements the MediaPlayer API while adding variable speed playback.  Unfortunately, it only provides audio.  Since I didn't want two different PlaybackService classes (one for audio, one for video) both doing mostly the same stuff, I created an interface called IPlayer that has all of the methods of the current MediaPlayer.  I then subclassed the aocate MediaPlayer as AudioPlayer and the android MediaPlayer as VideoPlayer, both implementing the IPlayer interface. They're essentially wrappers of their supertypes so that I could keep a consistent interface.

Since we can't reuse the same MediaPlayer object for audio and video files, I made a few additional changes to the PlaybackService to use a different MediaPlayer object for every file being played.

Both MediaPlayer classes have their own nested interfaces that both expect their own type.  In order to not duplicate callback code (i.e., one interface that takes com.aocate.*.MediaPlayer, and one that takes android.*.MediaPlayer, but otherwise have the exact same code), I added a DuckType class to essentially force the IPlayer interface onto those classes at runtime.  I adapted the class from here: http://thinking-in-code.blogspot.com/2008/11/duck-typing-in-java-using-dynamic.html
title: Variable Speed Playback

body:
When scrolling the list in the `OrganizeQueueActivity`, items can easily be removed from the list by accident (this happened to me several times). And, if your queue is pretty full, it can be difficult to find those items in order to add them back.

This branch adds an UndoBar like the one from the official GMail app based on Roman Nurik's [UndoBar](https://plus.google.com/u/0/+RomanNurik/posts/RA9WEEGWYp6).

One problem with this implementation could be that in response to the removal of the item, the `FeedManager` might delete the item's media and start auto-downloading new episodes. These actions can currently not be undone. Maybe it would make sense to just remove the item and schedule the cleanup and auto-download for when the user leaves the activity.
title: Make removal of queued items undoable

When a feed contains links to alternate feeds like in the example below, the last alternate link will override the website link, because the feed parser fails to check the link's MIME-Type.
```xml
<link>http://einschlafen-podcast.de</link>
<atom:link rel="self" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast (aac))" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/aac/" />
<atom:link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast)" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/mp3/" />
<atom:link rel="alternate" type="application/rss+xml" title="Einschlafen Podcast (Einschlafen Podcast (Opus))" href="http://einschlafen-podcast.de/feed/opus/" />
```

Hi there,

Version 0.9.7 was unusable but *.7.2 is much nicer.

But the new interface still has some issues:

 * **Titles in lists are shorted**: That's not just a problem of podcast with stupid episode titles (like "episode 45: something about the topic"), but also of podcast with complex topics ("Maskierte Mykotoxine - …"). And maybe a problems for languages with longer words or compounds. 
 * **Play/Pause/forward/…-Buttons are tiny and don't use the given space**: In older Version the big Play/Pause-Button was VERY helpful. The button should be bigger and all buttons together should use the space efficiently.
 * **It's hard to go from Cover to shownotes**: Thats really annoying, if you have a phone with a big screen or a short thumb its impossible to change between cover and shownotes. Please (re-)enable swipe there or make the whole "title area" (in the player) clickable, instead of just the little picture.
 * **Remember state of cover ←→ shownotes**: If you change from cover to shownotes and lock your phone antennapod will display the cover, or if you go to the playlist and then back to the player. Thats really annoying. （╯°□°）╯︵(\ .o.)\   And please the position of the shownotes, so you don't have to scroll AGAIN if you where in the playlist and the shownotes are "scrolled back".
 * **Global Sleeptimer**: The Sleeptimer should be reachable via GUI from everywhere (playlist, player episode, details, podcast list) and also be global. Now: If you say 30 min in the sleeptimer and your episode ends after 10 min the sleeptime disappears: (ಠ_ಠ)
 * **Playlist jumps to the start**: We had this bug several versions ago. So: If you play number 10 in the playlist and the episode ends, antennapod jumps to number 1 in the playlist, not 11 (or 10 which would be away) .

But at all the new interface is more efficient. I don't tap as often as before. ʘ‿ʘ

Greetings and sorry for this heap of bugs.
lof
title: Problems with new interface (0.9.7+)

body:
I came across this bug because "Waiting List" was not sorted properly. Then i realized it was a date parsing problem with some feeds.

Short year format specification works in both cases. Long year didn't. You can check docs if you want:
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html#applyPattern(java.lang.String)

The code has been tested with both types of year spec:
- Long format like "2013", which worked both before and after the patch. Eg: http://feeds.feedburner.com/droidcast/
- Short format like "13", which parsed nonsense timestamps (literally year 13 A.D.) before patch and now works. Eg: http://www.ivoox.com/portada-ivoox_fh.xml
title: Fix date format parsing

body:
The current behavior seems to queue newest episodes first, which can be a little bit confusing/jarring when you finish listening to recent episodes, and suddenly jump backward in time.

I imagine that not all users would prefer doing it this way, it might be best to have this configurable, possibly with a per-feed option and a global default.

I see two primary listening scenarios:
1. The user wants to listen to every episode on the subscription in the order which they come  out.
2. The user has more feeds than can all be followed, and wants to listen to whatever is recent. In this case, older episodes could eventually fall off the list

I suppose there is also the potential for wanting to listen to everything, _and_ wanting to hear them newest to oldest, but I'm not sure what the prevalence for that is (and maybe I am actually in the minority).

This could work nicely with #71 as well, with the priority taking precedence, then date-time ordering.
title: Episodes should auto-queue in order oldest to newest (or allow configuring the order)

I have been trying the test version for a couple days and it seems to check for new episodes, add them to the queue and download them automatically alright when I press the Refresh button.

The only problem I see is that I have to press the button. The idea behind making everything automatic is that the user can add the podcasts he wants and forget about AntennaPod, and the app will still do its thing and serve him new episodes in a silver plate.

To manage that the app shouldn't wait until the user opens it and presses Refresh. It should keep working in the background, checking for new episodes every so often (Daily? When the phone is charging and on WiFi?) and if it finds them, enqueue and download them automatically.

And of course then let the user know, which is issue #122.
title: Check for new episodes automatically

body:
This suggestion is included in a couple other issues (e.g. #125) but I think it's worth having its own issue.

Now that episodes are added to the waiting list and the playing queue automatically, we need an easy way to dismiss the ones that don't interest us. Swiping away is the quickest and handiest way, and the one many Google apps (e.g. Gmail) are favouring:

![Swipe](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244618/0d5d9a26-8a6b-11e2-9b03-788207dcea61.png)

![Swipe2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244621/1110244a-8a6b-11e2-9332-d8332db43f23.png)

The user would just have to flick their finger to the left or right, and the episode is dismissed. Unlistened episodes (that is, those the user never even started listening) would be deleted and forgotten, and listened ones (even partially listened ones) would be skipped and go to the History.

It could even be used at the top of the queue (that is, on the current episode) to skip the current episode and start listening to the next one, which would be an easy way to implement Skip without having to use extra buttons or UI elements.
title: Swipe episodes away

body:
Here's a couple mockups of AntennaPod if it used a dropdown to move between sections instead of tabs:

![Dropdown](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244538/7dcedcc8-8a68-11e2-93a1-4ab5c43ddf8d.png)

![Dropdown2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/244563/55e5cf68-8a69-11e2-8c70-b5b0bbce67fe.png)

I have several reasons to think that this would be better than we have now:

- First, it would save space. Once you have subscribed to the desired podcasts (and once auto-download and auto-enqueue are implemented) the user shouldn't really have a lot of reasons to switch between sections. He will probably spend most of the time in the Episodes section, so I think that the saved space will become more important than being able to change sections quickly.
- Second, it would allow to move the History section into the dropdown. Which, being a section and not an action, I think would make more sense than having it inside the overflow menu.
- Third and most important, it would allow to swipe episodes away. Unwanted episodes could be dismissed very quickly, with the flick of a finger. Which will become very important once new episodes are added automatically to the waiting list. It's important to note that swiping away is impossible with the current approach because horizontal movement just changes sections.
title: Use a dropdown instead of tabs

body:
The regression came with the use of AndroidHttpClient, where URLs are strictly validated.
The fix uses RedirectHandler to rewrite/fix broken URLs in case of redirection. AndroidHttpClient does not allow setting of RedirectHandler, therefore DefaultHttpHandler has been put in place.

Potential issues:
* DefaultHttpHandler implements the same interface as AndroidHttpClient, but does not support close() call (It seems that newer API will support it).  I assume, that GC is able to deal with it.
title: Fixed regression, issue #96

body: After AntennaPod automatically downloads and enqueues a number of episodes, it would be useful to have a notification that reads "There are X new items ready to listen" and has a "Play" button to start listening right away.

body:
Several issues suggest using auto-download. In order to have that we need the app to do the following:

- Devote some of the phone's memory to store podcasts when they are added to the playing queue.
- Erase already listened episodes in order to make room for new ones.

This brings two problems:

- There needs to be a way to decide how much space is given.
- Episodes shouldn't be erased IMMEDIATELY after being listened, because if you like an episode and want to listen to it again you would have to use additional data. As a result, there needs to be a way to decide how much space is given to listened episodes.

Therefore, two settings are needed:

- Disk space for cached episodes (by default: 10%).
- Disk space for listened episodes (by default: 5%).

If you had a phone with 8GB memory AntennaPod would automatically download and enqueue new episodes until they reached 800MB, at which point it would stop. Additionally, listened episodes would be kept until they reached 400MB, at which point the older ones would be deleted from the memory.

A user with a lower-end phone but really into podcasts could use those settings in order to devote more space.
title: Reserve some space to cache enqueued items and to keep listened ones.

body:
I don't think I have ever fully grasped what a "New" episode is. I guess it's new because it's been added recently? How recently? When does a new episode stop being new? Do I need to listen to it for it to become old, or does it automatically after some time?

This suggestion is kind of related to #79 in that new and old episodes are added to the same list. The suggestion is to do away with the concept of "New" episodes and replace it with a concept much easier to grasp: "Downloaded" vs. "Undownloaded" episodes.

![49d18e40-8511-11e2-9a30-e8ca5e71401c](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/226725/5f90703c-863f-11e2-9f05-a23eed6ed085.png)

The idea is that you have only one queue, and all new episodes are added to the bottom of that queue. The ones at the top are downloaded automatically when you have a WiFi connection, and then deleted after you listen to them in order to make room for new ones.

That way you always have fresh new episodes ready to be listened without having to use 3G data, and you never have to worry about which ones you download because the application takes care of that by itself.

Why separate downloaded episodes from undownloaded ones, then, if it's just one list? To let you know which ones you can listen to without using your data connection. That way, if there is one episode that attracts you in the "Undownloaded" section you can download it while you're at home, which will add it to "Downloaded" and let you listen to it on the go.
title: Instead of "Queued" and "New", use "Downloaded" and "Undownloaded"

When a download fails, the app leaves the file from the download on the sd-card. When the download is retried, it creates a new file with "-1" attached to the filename. If that fails again, it proceeds with "-2" and so on. 
Only the last file (the download that finally worked) will be recognized by the app and can be deleted afterwards. There is no possibility to delete those other files from within the app.
title: Files from failed downloads are never deleted.

Let me start off by saying thank you for producing high quality open source software and sharing it with everyone. I have been wanting to mess with android app development for a while, and I have started hacking at your code to understand how things work. Anyways, I've been playing around with the Google Reader API in the hopes of adding (some level of) google reader functionality to AntennaPod. 

At the very least it would be trivial to get an OAuth2 token from Android and then access the OMPL for a particular label directly from google reader as an import option (I've already gotten this level of functionality working in a dummy app). This would be way easier than the current OMPL import functionality and would only require one extra permission (USE_CREDENTIALS or something). 

Taking the idea further, one could imagine using google reader as a full on sync target for all feeds and read/unread statuses. This isn't so much a feature request as a request to gauge interest. If there is interest in such a feature (I know that Issue #21 is sort of a request in this direction) and no one is working on it, I'd like to contribute. If not, I can just try to develop the changes in a fork that I'll use myself and won't submit to Google Play.
title: Google Reader Integration

body:
As a user, I don't really think of "new" episodes as opposed to "queued" ones. I just want to know what new stuff there is to hear, and operate the app while giving it as little thought as possible. I would AntennaPod's interface to reflect this.

I made a quick mockup that you can see here:

![podcast 2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/694794/23233/8a471234-4a2d-11e2-88f2-5fd28272b456.png)

As you see there's still a "Feeds" tab, but the "New" and "Queued" tabs are replaced by a single "Episodes" one. The episode being played is at the top of it, with some control buttons.

Right below it are the episodes that have been downloaded and are ready to be listened. When the current episode ends, it goes to the History and is replaced by the first item in the list.

Old, listened items are removed automatically and make room for new ones to be downloaded (also automatically) and added to the list.

This way, supposing I have already subscribed to a selection of feeds that I like, I can keep listening to new episodes without ever worrying to check for new episodes, or having to download newer ones or reorder the list, or even ever leaving the "Episodes" screen.

As a user, I would only have to press "Play" to start listening and "Pause" to stop, and no further action would ever be required from me.
title: Merge "New" and "Queue" tabs for easier use

body:
I use Antennapod on two devices and on one of them, when I try to download a podcast episode, I receive the message "An error occurred when trying to donwload the file: Failed to access the external storage". Also, when I update the episodes list, the download fails and I receive the message "IO error: /mnt/sdcard/Android/data/de.danoeh.antennapod/files/cache/feed-CBN - Podcast - No Divã do Gikovate (Invalid argument)"

On the other device, this feed works without any problem. I've already tried to exclude the feed and delete this cache directory but It didn't help although It seems like some cache or temporary files problem... Is there any other directory I may clean or exclude to try to make this feed work ?

Thank you,

Regards,

Renato.

When importing an OPML file, the text field is displayed to the user when picking which subscriptions to import, rather than the title feed. E.g. with:

body:
The changes in this branch all revolve about the concept of episodes that were started listening to but aren't finished yet.

* The feed list shows the count of "in progress" episodes in addition to the count of the "new" episodes, both with a colored label so they can easily be distinguished
* The feed item list shows a colored label indicating the "read"/"unread"/"in progress" state. This makes it a lot easier to find "this one episode I think I started listening to but I can't really remember which one it was"
* Episodes that are currently "in progress" can be marked either "new" (and will consequently start from the beginning the next time they are played) or "read"
title: Labels indicating feeds and items "read"/"unread"/"in progress" counts and states

body:
One of the annoyances I've had with trying out any new podcast app is that I have to manually re-type in the urls of all of the podcasts that I have already subscribed to in Google Listen. This is true of AntennaPod as well, because few of the podcasts I want are in the Miro guide. I suspect that I am not the only one with this issue. I also suspect (though I don't _know_) that Listen is the most widely used podcatcher on Android.

Perhaps is would help adoption of the app if the user could easily import their existing podcast subscriptions in Listen. I know nothing of what is involved in implementing such a feature, or if it is even possible.

I believe a similar feature exists in Firefox for Android, where bookmarks and cookies can be imported from "Browser".

Thanks for your attention

Tony

PS: None of this would be (as much of) an issue if I could get Firefox (or Browser) to subscribe to a podcast by simply tapping on the RSS link. Perhaps I'm just missing something obvious.
title: Feature Request: Importing from Google Listen

body:
First off, thank you for your work. I'm glad someone has put together a good open source podcast app to replace Google Listen. Now, on to the problem.

When I add two feeds from the CBC no new entry is created for the second one, but podcasts for the second start appearing in the list for the first.  The CBC seems to be keeping all their XML files in the same directory (and this may be the source of the problem). To reproduce this, add the following feed:

"http://www.cbc.ca/podcasting/includes/spark.xml"

For me it shows up correctly in the feeds tab

Then add

"http://www.cbc.ca/podcasting/includes/writersandco.xml"

No new feed appears, but podcasts for the second feed start to appear in the list for the first. To me this seems to be incorrect behaviour.

 Perhaps the URL used for the first feed is being replaced with the second -- I can't tell from what I'm seeing. You can reverse the order of adding the feeds -- the first feed added appears, the second always gets "added" to the first. If either feed is on a _different_ host (for example NPR) two separate feeds are created and seem to work correctly.

Perhaps the problem is that both of these XML files contain the link to the same site: "http://www.cbc.ca/podcasting", even though they are different and separate feeds.

Thanks again.

Tony
title: Adding podcasts from same source

title: Startup Problems

body:
Hi,

in my eyes has your software the most potential to will the best podcast app on android market. :)

1. Playlist Support (minimum Audio and Video Podcast playlist)
2. podcast will delete after listen 
2.a. mark podcast to hold on the phone
3. "cloud" sync for multiple devices
4. Video Playback (i can not test it on my phone during crashes)

i hope you will bring much more tools on the app.

regards,
Thomas
title: Feature Request

body: Since android 2.3 there is this [download manager](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/DownloadManager.html) thing, which handles http downloads. Would it be possible to use the android download manager for downloading podcasts via AntennaPod?
title: Feature Request: Support downloads via android download manager

body: Hey, I'd would be create if Settings could include an option to change the background color to black. Most if not all my apps have that. Thanks!
title: Dark Skin

body:
It would be great if AntennaPod could show pictures embedded in "enhanced podcast" m4a files like the iPhone does.

Example feed: http://www.schoene-ecken.de/feed/podcast/
title: Support for embedded images in MP4 Enhanced Podcast files

body:
I have Novo7 Paladin tablet: http://www.ainovo.com/novo7paladin-specs.html and I don't see AntennaPod in Google Play on this device. At the same time other podcast managers (podkicker, doggcatcher) are available. Also, I downloaded and installed apk on this device and it works perfectly.

Is there something in android manifest which could be the reason for this?
title: Availability in Google Play

body:
Is wiould be great if AntennaPod would be available in languages other than English.
It could be done using https://www.transifex.com/ for example.
I'd volunteer to translate it to Russian.
title: Feature request: Localization

body: Could you add a .nomedia file to the directory where antennapod stores podcast images and podcasts by default? Because this will prevent the gallery from indexing podcast covers. Besides it will prevent music players from indexing podcasts, which is a usefull thing(at least I think so).
title: Feature request: .nomedia file

body:
I am not so sure if this is a bug or if this is a feature but I think the back button in the top left corner should take me to the previous antennapod screen(even if this is some kind of a duplicated functionality because the android back button alreday does that kind of thing).
For example if you select a podcast in the new screen and press the top left corner button it will take you to the screen which displays all podcasts of this specific podcast and not the previous screen(which was the new screen in this example).
title: The "back button" in the top left corner behaves some kind of strange

body: I don't know if this is a bug or if this is planned but AntennaPod also displays me RSS Items which doesn't have a enclosure tag and because AntennaPod is a podcatcher I would prefer it if it would only display those items which actually have a enclosure tag.
title: Display only those feed items which have a enclosure tag

body: I am not able to listen to Podcasts in the ogg vorbis format, I can download them with AntennaPod and play them with my music player, but I can't directly play them with AntennaPod.
title: Playback Problems

body: I always have the problem that I can't find the podcast that I have already downloaded when I am offline. Therefore I asked myself if it would be possible to add an option which would automatically add every downloaded Podcast to the queue?
title: Suggestion: Automatically add downloaded items to queue

body:
When adding a new feed the text "Type in the URL of the Feed here" is at the same position as the "confirm" and "cancel" which looks somekind of strange...

Here is a screenshot:
![](http://files.neuntausend.org/scrot/antennapod_addfeed.png)

It's probably a known issue but I thought it would be better to report it incase it isn't.
title: The "Add a new Feed" screen looks some kind of strange
